revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1945 in sports''' describes the year’s events in world sport.
Note — ''many sporting events did not take place because of [[World War II]]''
==[[American football]]== * [[1945 Cleveland Rams season|Cleveland Rams]] defeated [[1945 Washington Redskins season|the Washington Redskins]] 15-14 at [[Cleveland, Ohio]] to win the [[1945 NFL Championship Game|NFL]] championship; the Rams relocate after the season to [[Los Angeles]] * [[Army Black Knights|Army Cadets]] – [[college football]] national championship
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * With the end of [[World War II]], the [[FA Cup]] is reinstated for the [[1945–46 in English football|1945–46]] season; played on a two–legged basis. However, clubs are not yet prepared for a full league programme, so the [[Football League]] does not resume; regional leagues remain for another year. '''France''' * 26 August: [[1945–46 French Division 1|French Division 1]] football is resumed for the first time since [[1938–39 French Division 1|1938–39]]. '''Germany''' * There is no major football in Germany due to World War II and [[Allied-occupied Germany|the Allied occupation]]. '''Portugal''' * [[1944–45 Primeira Divisão|Primeira Liga]] won by [[S.L. Benfica]]. '''Spain''' * [[1944-45 La Liga|La Liga]] won by [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]]. '''Italy''' * [[Serie A]] – not contested due to [[World War II]].
==[[Australian rules football]]== * [[1945 VFL season|Victorian Football League]] ** Carlton wins the 49th VFL Premiership defeating [[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne]] 15.13 (103) to 10.15 (75) [[1945 VFL Grand Final|in the Grand Final]]. * [[South Australian National Football League]]: ** 29 September: [[West Torrens Football Club|West Torrens]] win their third SANFL premiership, defeating [[Port Adelaide Football Club (SANFL)|Port Adelaide]] 15.25 (115) to 15.12 (102). * [[1945 WANFL season|Western Australian National Football League]]: ** 29 March: After three seasons of football limited to players under 18 or 19, and a proposal to limit eligibility to players under 25, the WANFL decides to restore open-age league football.<ref>“League Football – An Open Competition: Decision for 1945 Season”; ''[[The West Australian]]'', 23 March 1945, p. 2</ref> ** 13 October: [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]] 12.15 (87) defeat [[South Fremantle Football Club|South Fremantle]] 7.9 (51) for their nineteenth senior WANFL premiership.
==[[Baseball]]== * [[1945 World Series|World Series]] – [[Detroit Tigers]] defeat the [[Chicago Cubs]], 4 games to 3. * [[1945 Negro World Series|Negro World Series]] – [[Cleveland Buckeyes]] swept the [[Homestead Grays]], 4 games to 0.
==[[Basketball]]== '''NBL Championship''' *[[Fort Wayne Zollner Pistons]] win three games to two over the [[Sheboygan Redskins]] '''Events''' * The twelfth [[South American Basketball Championship 1945|South American Basketball Championship]] in [[Guayaquil]] is won by [[Brazil national basketball team|Brazil]]. '''Serbia''' *[[KK Crvena zvezda]], as known well for professional basketball club of [[Serbia]], officially founded on March 3. {{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
==[[Cricket]]== '''England''' *With the end of [[European theatre of World War II|World War II in Europe]], a small number of [[first-class cricket|first-class matches]] are played for the first time since [[1939 English cricket season|1939]], but it is not practicable to resume the [[County Championship]] or the [[Minor Counties Championship]]. *Most runs – [[Len Hutton]] 782 @ 48.87 (HS 188) *Most wickets – [[Dick Pollard]] 28 @ 24.25 (BB 6–75) '''Australia''' * 23 November – With the lifting of bans on weekday sport at the end of [[World War II]], first-class cricket is played in Australia for the first time since 1 December 1941. The [[Sheffield Shield]], however, is not contested until the following season. '''India''' * 4–8 March: [[C. S. Nayudu|Cottari Subbanna Nayudu]] of [[Holkar cricket team|Holkar]] sets two first-class records in the Ranji Trophy final against [[Bombay cricket team|Bombay]], bowling 912 balls and conceding 428 runs in the match.<ref>Webber, Roy; ''The Playfair Book of Cricket Records''; pp. 163-165. Published 1951 by Playfair Books.</ref> * [[Ranji Trophy]] – Bombay beat Holkar by 374 runs * [[Bombay Quadrangular|Bombay Pentangular]] – [[Hindus cricket team|Hindus]] '''New Zealand''' * 24 December: The [[Plunket Shield]] is resumed after having not been contested, despite a small number of interprovincial first-class matches, since 1939–40. '''South Africa''' * 15 December: With the end of [[World War II]], first-class cricket is played in South Africa for the first time since 14 March 1943, though the last regular interprovincial matches had been in 1939–40.
==[[Cycling]]== '''[[List of Tour de France winners|Tour de France]]''' * not contested due to [[World War II]] '''[[Giro d'Italia]]''' * not contested due to [[World War II]]
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * not contested due to [[World War II]]
==[[Golf]]== '''Men's professional''' * [[Masters Tournament]] – not played due to [[World War II]] * [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] – not played due to [[World War II]] * [[The Open Championship|British Open]] – not played due to [[World War II]] * [[1945 PGA Championship|PGA Championship]] – [[Byron Nelson]] * [[PGA Tour]] money leader – [[Byron Nelson]] – $63,336 '''Men's amateur''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – not played due to [[World War II]] * [[U.S. Amateur]] – not played due to [[World War II]] '''Women's professional''' * [[Women's Western Open]] – [[Babe Zaharias]] * [[Titleholders Championship]] – not played due to [[World War II]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''Steeplechases''' * [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] – [[Red Rower]] * [[Grand National]] – ''not held due to [[World War II]]'' '''Hurdle races''' * [[Champion Hurdle]] – [[Brains Trust (horse)|Brains Trust]] '''Flat races''' * Australia – [[Melbourne Cup]] won by [[Rainbird (horse)|Rainbird]] * Canada – [[Queen's Plate]] won by [[Uttermost]] * France – [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] won by Nikellora * Ireland – [[Irish Derby Stakes]] won by [[Piccadilly (horse)|Piccadilly]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|English Triple Crown Races]]: *# [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Court Martial (horse)|Court Martial]] *# [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Dante (horse)|Dante]] *# [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Chamossaire (horse)|Chamossaire]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|United States Triple Crown Races]]: *# [[1945 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – [[Hoop Jr.]] *# [[Preakness Stakes]] – [[Polynesian (horse)|Polynesian]] *# [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Pavot]]
==[[Ice hockey]]== * [[1945 Stanley Cup Finals|Stanley Cup]]: [[1944–45 Toronto Maple Leafs season|Toronto Maple Leafs]] beat [[1944–45 Detroit Red Wings season|Detroit Red Wings]] four games to three.
==[[Motor racing]]== * [[Indianapolis 500]] – ''not held due to [[World War II]]'' * 9 September – The first European [[Grands Prix during World War II|Grand Prix]] since [[1939 Grand Prix season|1939]] is held in Paris, being won by [[Jean-Pierre Wimille]].
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] is not contested due to World War II
==[[Rugby league]]== *[[1945–46 European Rugby League Championship]] *[[1945 New Zealand rugby league season]] *[[1945 NSWRFL season]] *[[1944–45 Northern Rugby Football League Wartime Emergency League season]] / [[1945–46 Northern Rugby Football League season]]
==[[Rugby union]]== * [[Six Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is not contested due to World War II
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * not contested due to [[World War II]]
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – ''not contested'' * [[List of Australian Open Women's Singles champions|Australian Women's Singles Championship]] – ''not contested'' '''England''' * [[List of Wimbledon Gentlemen's Singles champions|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – ''not contested'' * [[List of Wimbledon Ladies' Singles champions|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – ''not contested'' '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Yvon Petra]] (France) defeats [[Bernard Destremau]] (France) 7–5, 6–4, 6–2 * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Lolette Payot]] (Switzerland) defeats [[Simone Iribarne Lafargue]] (France) 6–3, 6–4 '''USA''' * [[List of US Open Men's Singles champions|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Frank Parker]] (USA) defeats [[Bill Talbert]] (USA) 14–12, 6–1, 6–2 * [[List of US Open Women's Singles champions|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Sarah Palfrey Cooke]] (USA) defeats [[Pauline Betz Addie]] (USA) 3–6, 8–6, 6–4 '''Davis Cup''' * 1945 International Lawn Tennis Challenge – ''not contested''
==References== {{Reflist}}

The '''1980 [[Ms. Olympia]]''' contest was an [[International Federation of BodyBuilders|IFBB]] [[professional bodybuilding]] competition was held in August 30, 1980, at the Sheraton Hotel in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]]. It was the 1st Ms. Olympia competition held.
==Prize Money== *1st $5,000 '''Total: $10,000'''<ref>[http://www.colettenelson.com/publicity2007/Msolympiamusclemag2007/images/02-04-2007%2003;06;38PM.jpg Ms. Olympia by the numbers ]</ref>

revision.text: The '''Albert Ground''' was a cricket ground located in the [[Sydney]] suburb of [[Redfern, New South Wales|Redfern]] between 1864 and 1877. ==History== [[File:Albert Ground Sydney.jpg|thumb|Lithograph of an 1876 [[intercolonial cricket in Australia|intercolonial cricket]] match between [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]] and [[Victorian cricket team|Victoria]] at the Albert Ground]] [[Cricket]] had been played in [[NSW]] since 1803, first in [[Hyde Park, Sydney|Hyde Park]] and then in the [[The Domain, Sydney|Domain]]. Neither were satisfactory facilities mainly because they were open grounds on which spectators walked and animals grazed. Fences could not be erected to keep people and animals out or to charge much needed admission. When the Albert Ground opened in Redfern on 29 October 1864, these problems appeared to be solved. The ground had been developed as a money-making venture in the swampy area that Redfern was at the time. Despite this, the Albert Ground had significant advantages over Sydney’s existing cricket facilities. It was centrally located and featured good facilities for players and crowd alike. There was a grandstand in the north west corner and a pavilion ran around three sides of the ground. A row of trees had been planted by the [[English cricket]] tourists of 1863-1864 captained by [[George Parr (cricketer)|George Parr]]. The pitch was made of a matted [[Cynodon dactylon|couch grass]] and was very spongy and soft. It was a slow pitch that favoured the bowlers. The ground was the home of the Albert Club, one of the most powerful in Sydney, which could boast three teams of 11. The club’s players wore white caps and pants and blue shirts and counted amongst their number the greatest bowler of the day ‘The Demon’ [[Fred Spofforth]]. Above all however, the Albert Ground had been established as a business with the aim of making money and fees were charged to those who wanted to use it, including the [[New South Wales Cricket Association|NSW Cricket Association]]. The cost to the NSWCA of staging matches there was so high that until the early 1870s it continued to use the Domain whenever possible despite its disadvantages. By then inter-colonial games had become so important and popular that the NSWCA had little choice but to use the Albert Ground for these at least. In all, five first-class matches were played at the Albert Ground between the 1870 and 1877 seasons. In the late 1870s however, the Albert Ground company was wound up and the ground closed. The NSWCA began using the Garrison Ground at [[Moore Park, New South Wales|Moore Park]], later to be renamed the Association Ground and then the [[Sydney Cricket Ground]]. Eventually the Albert Ground was demolished. The Albert Ground was located to the east of Redfern Park in the block now roughly bounded by Elizabeth, Redfern, Kettle and Moorehead Streets. The site is now occupied by public housing. ==List of cricket matches== Below is a list of the [[first-class cricket]] matches that were played at the Albert Ground. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size: 95%" |- ! Season ! Teams ! Date ! Result ! Ref |- | 1870–71 | [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]] v [[Victoria cricket team|Victoria]] | 1871-03-09 9–11, 13 March 1871 | Victoria won by 48 runs | {{cite web|title=New South Wales v Victoria, 1870–71|url=http://static.espncricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/1870S/1870-71/AUS_LOCAL/NSW_VIC_09-13MAR1871.html|website=[[ESPNcricinfo]]|publisher=[[ESPN Inc.]]|accessdate=24 November 2013}} |- | 1872–73 | New South Wales v Victoria | 1873-02-28 28 February–2, 7–8 March 1873 | Victoria won by 24 runs | {{cite web|title=New South Wales v Victoria, 1872–73|url=http://static.espncricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/1870S/1872-73/AUS_LOCAL/NSW_VIC_28FEB-08MAR1873.html|website=[[ESPNcricinfo]]|publisher=[[ESPN Inc.]]|accessdate=24 November 2013}} |- | 1874–75 | New South Wales v Victoria | 1875-03-05 5–6, 8 March 1875 | New South Wales won by 77 runs | {{cite web|title=New South Wales v Victoria, 1874–75|url=http://static.espncricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/1870S/1874-75/AUS_LOCAL/NSW_VIC_05-08MAR1875.html|website=[[ESPNcricinfo]]|publisher=[[ESPN Inc.]]|accessdate=24 November 2013}} |- | 1875–76 | New South Wales v Victoria | 1876-02-25 25–26, 28 February 1876 | New South Wales won by 195 runs | {{cite web|title=New South Wales v Victoria, 1875–76|url=http://static.espncricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/1870S/1875-76/AUS_LOCAL/NSW_VIC_25-28FEB1876.html|website=[[ESPNcricinfo]]|publisher=[[ESPN Inc.]]|accessdate=24 November 2013}} |- | 1876–77 | New South Wales v [[James Lillywhite]]'s XI | 1877-01-15 15–16 January 1877 | Match drawn | {{cite web|title=New South Wales v James Lillywhite's XI, 1876–77 |subscription=yes |url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/2/2075.html|website=CricketArchive|accessdate=24 November 2013}} |} ==References== {{reflist}} Cashman, Richard (1990) ''‘The Demon’ Spofforth'' Kensington: UNSW Press Pollard, Jack (1990) ''Australia'' In: '''Test Match Grounds''' London: Willow Books Vamplew, Wray; Moore, Katharine; O’Hara, John; Chashman, Richard; and Jobling, Ian [editors] (1997) ''The Oxford Companion to Australian Sport'' Second Edition Melbourne: Oxford University Press Willis, James (1868) ''Map of Port Jackson and City of Sydney showing the adjacent municipalities NSW'' In: '''Sydney Takes Shape: A history in maps''' Paul Ashton and Duncan Waterson editors Brisbane: HEMA Maps 2000. ==External links== * [http://www-aus.cricket.org Cricinfo.com] {{Coord|33|53.7|S|151|12.5|E|type:landmark_region:AU-NSW|display=title}} [[Category:Defunct cricket grounds in Australia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1864]]

{{BLP sources|date=February 2009}} '''Armand Rousso''', also known as '''Marc Rousso''', is a [[France|French]] businessman. He is the founder of Accoona.com, a business-to-business search engine, and X3D Technology. He is the father of [[Vanessa Rousso]], professional [[poker]] player and [[Big Brother 17 (U.S.)|Big Brother]] contestant.
== Biography == French born entrepreneur Armand Rousso settled in the United States in 1982, working as a trader of stamps. In 1985 he stated he bartered $45 million (catalog value) in rare stamps.{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}}
In 1986, when the Internet was little known entity, Rousso started an online stamp exchange website, ''The International Stamp Exchange'', which lasted until 1990. The International Stamp Exchange was part of a network by David N. Glassman who created NaicoNet the first online retail online stock trading system. He thought online advertising revenues could be lucrative enough to make a business dedicated to philatelists profitable. Rousso and the ISE are profiled in the March 28, 1988 issue of [[New York Magazine]].
In the mid 1990s, Rousso became involved with Philippe V. Hababou, a Frenchman convicted of check fraud. In 1998, he pleaded guilty to securities fraud and money-laundering charges; in 1999, he was convicted of securities fraud in France and was also noted in the investigation over illegal campaign contributions to the 1996 Senate campaign of [[Robert G. Torricelli]].<ref name="misgivings"/>
Rousso was identified as having bought at auction the [[Treskilling Yellow]], a unique Swedish [[postage stamp]] printed in the wrong color.<ref>[http://stamps.about.com/od/buyingsellingstamps/qt/Mystery-Owner-Of-Treskilling-Yellow-Rarity-Revealed.htm John Finch, Mystery Owner of Treskilling Yellow Rarity Revealed, Entrepreneur and Fixture on the Philatelic Scene]</ref> The stamp had been auctioned on 22 May 2010, by David Feldman in Geneva, Switzerland, for at least $2.3 million, the world's record price for a stamp at auction. In May 2013 the stamp was acquired in a private sale by [[Gustaf Douglas|Count Gustaf Douglas]], a Swedish nobleman and politician.<ref>[http://www.stampmagazine.co.uk/news/article/treskilling-yellow-is-back-in-the-hands-of-a-philatelist/17013 Treskilling Yellow is back in the hands of a philatelist] by Julia Lee, stampmagazine.co.uk, 1 November 2013. Retrieved 6 November 2013. [https://www.webcitation.org/6KvVwRib9 Archived here.]</ref>
===Accoona search engine=== Rousso was founder of ''Accoona'', a [[Business-to-business|B2B]] search engine. Launched in 2004 with former President [[Bill Clinton]] as chief announcer,<ref name="b2b">{{cite web | last = Temple | first = David | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = B2B search engine Accoona acquired by Masterseek | work = | publisher = Multilingual Search | date = 2008-11-09 | url = http://www.multilingual-search.com/b2b-search-engine-accoona-acquired-by-masterseek/09/11/2008 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-03-10}}</ref> the company failed to gain any significant part of the search engine market, though the online electronics retailers it also owns did make the company money.<ref>{{cite news | last = Arrington | first = Michael | coauthors = | title = Twing: Accoona's Final Disgrace | work = [[The Washington Post]] | pages = | date = 2009-12-01 | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/12/02/AR2008120200035_pf.html | accessdate = 2009-03-10}}</ref> (Clinton reportedly made $700,000 for his Clinton Foundation in 2006 from selling Accoona stock.<ref>{{cite news | last = Zajac | first = Andrew | coauthors = | title = Bill Clinton and the Midas touch: Stock deal benefiting his foundation among shrouded successes | work = [[Chicago Tribune]] | pages = | date = 2008-03-04 | url = https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/1438761091.html?dids=1438761091:1438761091&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Mar+04%2C+2008&author=Andrew+Zajac&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=Bill+Clinton+and+the+Midas+touch&pqatl=google | accessdate = 2009-03-10}}</ref>) The initial $80.5 million offering was underwritten by Maxim Group. However, as ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported, "Accoona.com attracted only 106,000 visitors from the United States in July (2007), according to comScore, which monitors Internet traffic."<ref name="misgivings">{{cite news | last = Hansell | first = Saul | coauthors = | title = Misgivings Spoil Plans of Start-Up | work = [[The New York Times]] | pages = | date = 2007-08-22 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/22/technology/22accoona.html?em&ex=1188100800&en=48bad887ba36f354&ei=5087%0A | accessdate = 2009-03-10}}</ref> The underwriter withdrew, possibly as a result of Rousso's checkered past.<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Web search IPO stalls on underwriter doubts | publisher = [[CNN]] | date = 2007-08-22 | url = http://money.cnn.com/2007/08/22/markets/ipo/accoona/index.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2009-03-10}}</ref> In 2008, the company was acquired by [[Masterseek]].<ref name="b2b"/>
==Chess== Rousso is active in international chess and with his company X3D Technologies (which develops [[3D computer graphics|3-D]] technology for the internet<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Partnership formed on Chinese culture | work = | publisher = Chinadaily.com | date = 2003-10-22 | url = http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/en/doc/2003-10/22/content_274314.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2009-03-10| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090316200736/http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/en/doc/2003-10/22/content_274314.htm| archivedate= 16 March 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>) sponsored several World Championship Matches, including [[Garry Kasparov]] vs [[Anatoly Karpov]] (2002) and Garry Kasparov vs [[X3D Fritz]] (2003).<ref>{{cite web | last = Friedel | first = Frederic | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Entrepreneur, philanthropist, chess aficionado | work = | publisher = ChessBase.com | date = 2004-04-09 | url = http://www.chessbase.com/newsdetail.asp?newsid=1887 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-03-10}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rousso, Armand}} [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Stamp dealers]] [[Category:French emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Chess patrons]]

[[File:Charles Hoff.jpg|thumb|right|Charles Hoff]] '''Charles Hoff''' (9 May 1902 – 19 February 1985) was a [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[Athletics (sport)|athlete]], coach, sports journalist, novelist and sports administrator.
As an active athlete he competed in [[pole vault]], [[long jump]], [[triple jump]], [[sprint (running)|sprints]] and [[middle distance running]] events. He set four [[world records in athletics|world records]] [[World record progression pole vault men|in the pole vault]] during his career, became Norwegian champion ten times in different events, and competed in the [[1924 Summer Olympics]]. In 1926 he was excluded from the sport for [[Professional sport|professionalism]].
After his time as an athlete he took up a career as a sports journalist. During [[World War II]] he was a sports leader under the [[occupation of Norway by Nazi Germany|Nazi rule]], leading the [[Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports|Norwegian Confederation of Sports]] from 1942 to 1944.
==Early life== He was born in [[Fredrikstad]] as the son of mechanic Karl Ludvig Hoff and his wife Olga Kristine Karlsen. After taking the [[examen artium]] in 1921, he moved to [[Oslo|Kristiania]] to attend the [[Norwegian National Academy of Craft and Art Industry]]. He also briefly attended the [[Norwegian National Academy of Fine Arts]] as well as a painting school in [[Paris]].<ref name=nbl>{{cite encyclopedia|year=2001|title=Charles Hoff|encyclopedia=[[Norsk biografisk leksikon]]|first=Finn|last=Olstad|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget|editor=Helle, Knut|location=Oslo|url=http://www.snl.no/.nbl_biografi/Charles_Hoff/utdypning|accessdate=26 February 2009|language=Norwegian|editor-link=Knut Helle}}</ref>
==Athletics career== Hoff set his first [[world records in athletics|world record]] [[World record progression pole vault men|in the pole vault]] on 22 July 1922 in [[Copenhagen]] with 4.12 metres. He increased this record to 4.21 metres exactly one year later in the same city, then to 4.23 metres on 13 August 1925 in Oslo, and finally on 27 September 1925 when he jumped 4.25 metres at a meet in [[Turku]]. The record stood until May 1927, when American [[Sabin Carr]] jumped 4.27 metres.<ref name=athletix>{{cite news|url=http://athletix.org/?p=693.html|title=World Record Progression. Pole vault men|publisher=The Athletics Site|accessdate=26 February 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130414123753/http://athletix.org/?p=693.html|archivedate=14 April 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Hoff was the first Norwegian athlete to establish a world record, the only to do so before World War II, and the only Norwegian ever to do so in a jumping event.<ref name=rec>{{cite encyclopedia|year=2007|title=Friidrett|encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]]|editor=Henriksen, Petter|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget|location=Oslo|first=Rolf|last=Bryhn |url=http://www.snl.no/friidrett#menuitem21|accessdate=26 February 2009|language=Norwegian}}</ref> After World War II, world records have been set by several Norwegian throwers and runners: [[Sverre Strandli]], [[Audun Boysen]], [[Egil Danielsen]], [[Terje Pedersen]], [[Grete Waitz]], [[Ingrid Kristiansen]] and [[Trine Hattestad]].<ref name=rec/>
Internationally he competed at the [[1924 Summer Olympics]], in both [[Athletics at the 1924 Summer Olympics - Men's 400 metres|400]] and [[Athletics at the 1924 Summer Olympics – Men's 800 metres|800 metres]]. He reached the semi-final in the 400 metres and finished eighth in the 800 metres final. He did not participate in the [[Athletics at the 1924 Summer Olympics - Men's pole vault|pole vault]] due to an injured ankle.<ref name=snl>{{cite encyclopedia|year=2007|title=Charles Hoff|encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]]|editor=Henriksen, Petter|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget|location=Oslo|first=Rolf|last=Bryhn|author2=Knut Are Tvedt|url=http://www.snl.no/Charles_Hoff|accessdate=26 February 2009|language=Norwegian}}</ref> He was the Norwegian champion in the 200 metres from 1923 and 1924,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.friidrett.no/friidrett/statistikk/nm/m200.htm|title=Norwegian championships medallists, men's 200 metres|publisher=Norwegian Athletics Association|accessdate=21 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930202408/http://www.friidrett.no/friidrett/statistikk/nm/m200.htm |archivedate=2007-09-30}}</ref> in the 400 metres from 1924,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.friidrett.no/friidrett/statistikk/nm/m400.htm|title=Norwegian championships medallists, men's 400 metres|publisher=Norwegian Athletics Association|accessdate=21 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930202623/http://www.friidrett.no/friidrett/statistikk/nm/m400.htm |archivedate=2007-09-30}}</ref> in the pole vault from 1922, 1923, 1924, 1925 and 1933,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.friidrett.no/friidrett/statistikk/nm/mpv.htm|title=Norwegian championships medallists, men's pole vault|publisher=Norwegian Athletics Association|accessdate=21 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930185054/http://www.friidrett.no/friidrett/statistikk/nm/mpv.htm |archivedate=2007-09-30}}</ref> and in the triple jump from 1922 and 1923.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.friidrett.no/friidrett/statistikk/nm/mtj.htm|title=Norwegian championships medallists, men's triple jump|publisher=Norwegian Athletics Association|accessdate=21 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080205234039/http://www.friidrett.no/friidrett/statistikk/nm/mtj.htm |archivedate=2008-02-05}}</ref> Representing the sports club [[Torshaug IF]], Hoff won the King's Cup twice. In total he held fourteen Norwegian records in 200, 400 and 800 metres, long jump and pole vault.<ref name=snl/>
In the winter of 1926, Hoff toured the United States, staging show competitions as a part of a [[varieté]] performance group.<ref name=nbl/> Among other things he beat Olympic gold medalist [[Harold Osborn]] in a [[heptathlon]] competition.<ref name=snl/> He also set several unofficial world indoor records. Following this tour, however, he was considered to be a [[professional sport]]sperson. This affected his eligibility to compete in the sport of athletics as a whole, since the sport was governed under [[Amateur sports|amateurist]] rules at the time. Hoff explained that the paid performances were necessary to earn a living, as the [[Amateur Athletic Union]] had withheld some money that had been promised to Hoff in advance, but to no avail.<ref name=nbl/> Thus, when jumping a new world record of 4.32 metres in [[Hønefoss]] on 27 September 1931, the record was not ratified by the [[International Amateur Athletics Federation]] (IAAF).<ref name=athletix/>
==Non-active career== In December 1925 he married Heddy Aubert, a daughter of the [[Norsk Hydro|Director General of Norsk Hydro]], [[Axel Aubert]]. The marriage was dissolved after a few years, but Hoff married for the second time, this time to Aase Synnøve Bing Nilsen. Hoff was also a brother-in-law of [[Per Mørch Hansson]].<ref name=nbl/>
From 1927 to 1936 he was the editor of the sports magazine ''[[Sportsmanden]]''. He made his mark on ''Sportsmanden'' by emphasizing sensationalist news, front page headlines and the inclusion of pictures. The overall layout, which Hoff in retrospect described as "revolutionary", was inspired by his time in the United States. As a writer he was not uncontroversial, though, and after he was found guilty of libel, he was pressured by the magazine owner to resign. He found a new job as sports editor of ''Oslo Illustrerte'' from 1936 to 1940, and also wrote for the Nasjonal Samling party newspaper ''[[Fritt Folk]]'' in the late 1930s.<ref name=nbl/> He was also a coach in the [[Norwegian Athletics Association]].<ref name=nkl>{{cite encyclopedia|last=Tønnesson|first=Stein|authorlink=Stein Tønnesson|editor=Dahl, Hans Fredrik|encyclopedia=[[Norsk krigsleksikon 1940-45]]|title=Hoff, Charles (Carl Gunnøy)|url=http://mediabase1.uib.no/krigslex/h/h6.html#hoff-charles|accessdate=26 February 2009|edition=|year=1995|publisher=Cappelen|volume=|location=Oslo|isbn=|language=Norwegian|editor-link=Hans Fredrik Dahl|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315115128/http://mediabase1.uib.no/krigslex/h/h6.html#hoff-charles|archivedate=15 March 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===World War II=== When Norway was [[Operation Weserübung|invaded by Germany]] in April 1940, many Norwegian athletes volunteered to fight in the [[Norwegian Campaign]]. Hoff then made his mark as he called on the fighters to lay down their weapons and return to the sports field.<ref name=nkl/> For this he was sacked by the Norwegian Athletics Association.<ref name=nbl/> However, Germany was able to establish an [[occupation of Norway by Nazi Germany|occupation of Norway]], and soon moved to tighten their grip on Norwegian society. At this point Hoff contacted the ''[[Reichskommissar]]iat'' to propose a Nazi reorganization of sports life in Norway.<ref name=nkl/> In September 1940 he was given the position as deputy under-secretary of state in the new [[Norwegian Ministry of Labour and Sports|Ministry of Labour and Sports]],<ref name=nbl/> which was headed by [[Axel Heiberg Stang]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.regjeringen.no/en/The-Government/previous-governments/the-structure-of-the-registry/governments/norway-at-war/ministries-1940---1945---under-german-oc.html?id=438672|title=Norwegian Government Ministries 1940–1945—under German occupation in Oslo|publisher=[[Government.no]]|accessdate=27 February 2007}}</ref> He also joined the Nasjonal Samling at that time.<ref name=nbl/>
However, the Nazi interference with sports resulted in a nationwide boycott of official athletics meetings in Norway from the end of 1940.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |last=Tønnesson |first=Stein |editors=Dahl, Hjeltnes, Nøkleby, Ringdal, Sørensen |encyclopedia=Norsk krigsleksikon 1940-45 |title=idrettsstreik |url=http://mediabase1.uib.no/krigslex/i/i1.html#idrettsstreik |page=192 |year=1995 |publisher=Cappelen |volume= |location=Oslo |isbn=82-02-14138-9 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=27 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120301185901/http://mediabase1.uib.no/krigslex/i/i1.html#idrettsstreik |archivedate=1 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> When the reorganization of sports life was implemented in November 1940, the Germans, knowing that Hoff was unpopular, kept him out of the spotlight. [[Egil Reichborn-Kjennerud]] was installed as leader of the [[Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports|Norwegian Confederation of Sports]], while Hoff used the [[Hird (Nazi)|Hird]] as an arena for his work. In the spring of 1942, it became clear that Reichborn-Kjennerud had failed to deal with the still-ongoing sports boycott, and Hoff became the new leader of the Confederation of Sports.<ref name=nkl/> He had a number of grand plans; sports in Norway should be state-led, and the aim was to produce a broad range of athletes rather than a few stars. In addition to the physical dimension, the "spiritual" dimension should be emphasized.<ref name=nbl/> He originally received generous funding, but from 1943 Germany lost interest in his projects, and in 1944 the projects were largely disestablished. Hoff protested this decision, and was removed from his position as a result.<ref name=nkl/>
===Post-war life=== As a part of the [[legal purge in Norway after World War II]] in 1947 he was sentenced to nine years of forced labour.<ref name=nkl/> A number of his ideas were actually realized some years later, including a national school of sport sciences and a state-owned gambling company.<ref name=snl/> [[Norsk Tipping]] was established already in 1948, and the [[Norwegian School of Sport Sciences]] in 1968.
After serving his sentence, Hoff worked as an editor in the publishing house Hauge & Co. In 1952 he published the crime novel ''Døden i Bygdø Allé'', under the pseudonym Texas Bang. He had formerly published the novel ''Systemet'' in 1925 as well as a retelling of his experiences in the United States, titled ''Fra New York til Hollywood. Mine oplevelser i Amerika'', in 1927. Hoff died in 1985 in [[Oslo]].<ref name=nbl/>

[[File:Starting position in a chess game.jpg|thumb|220px|right|Chess initial position]]
The game of [[chess]] is commonly divided into three phases: the [[chess opening|opening]], [[Chess middlegame|middlegame]], and [[Chess endgame|endgame]].<ref>John Watson, ''Secrets of Modern Chess Strategy: Advances Since Nimzowitsch'', Gambit Publications, 1998, p. 10. {{ISBN|1-901983-07-2}}. {{ISBN|0-486-20290-9}}.</ref> There is a large body of theory regarding how the game should be played in each of these phases, especially the opening and endgame. Those who write about '''chess theory''', who are often also eminent players, are referred to as "theorists" or "theoreticians".
"Opening theory" commonly refers to consensus, broadly represented by current literature on the openings.<ref>[[David Hooper (chess player)|David Hooper]] and [[Kenneth Whyld]], ''[[The Oxford Companion to Chess]]'', Oxford University Press, 2nd ed. 1992, p. 418 ("theory" entry). {{ISBN|0-19-866164-9}}.</ref> "Endgame theory" consists of statements regarding specific positions, or positions of a similar type, though there are few universally applicable principles.<ref>Hooper and Whyld, p. 418.</ref> "Middlegame theory" often refers to maxims or principles applicable to the middlegame.<ref>Watson, ''Secrets of Modern Chess Strategy'', p. 10.</ref> The modern trend, however, is to assign paramount importance to analysis of the specific position at hand rather than to general principles.<ref>Watson, ''Secrets of Modern Chess Strategy'', p. 11.</ref>
The development of theory in all of these areas has been assisted by the vast literature on the game. In 1913, preeminent chess historian [[H. J. R. Murray]] wrote in his 900-page magnum opus ''[[A History of Chess]]'' that, "The game possesses a literature which in contents probably exceeds that of all other games combined."<ref>[[H. J. R. Murray]], ''A History of Chess'', Oxford University Press, 1913, p. 25. {{ISBN|0-19-827403-3}}. This quote is also given in Hooper and Whyld, p. 229 ("literature of chess" entry).</ref> He estimated that at that time the "total number of [[list of chess books|books on chess]], [[List of chess periodicals|chess magazines]], and newspapers devoting space regularly to the game probably exceeds 5,000".<ref>Murray, p. 25 n. 1.</ref> In 1949, [[Baruch Harold Wood|B. H. Wood]] estimated that the number had increased to about 20,000.<ref name="Hooper and Whyld, p. 229">Hooper and Whyld, p. 229.</ref><ref>See B. H. Wood, "Books About Chess", ''[[Illustrated London News]]'', 1949, reprinted in [[Fred Reinfeld]] (editor), ''The Treasury of Chess Lore'', Dover, 1959, pp. 268-70.</ref> [[David Hooper (chess player)|David Hooper]] and [[Kenneth Whyld]] wrote in 1992 that, "Since then there has been a steady increase year by year of the number of new chess publications. No one knows how many have been printed..."<ref name="Hooper and Whyld, p. 229"/> The world's largest [[chess libraries|chess library]], the [[John G. White]] Collection<ref>[http://ohchess.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=50&Itemid=1 The World's Greatest Chess Library]</ref> at the [[Cleveland Public Library]], contains over 32,000 chess books and serials, including over 6,000 bound volumes of chess periodicals.<ref>[http://spc.cpl.org/?q=node/5 Cleveland Public Library, Special Collections] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090305054915/http://spc.cpl.org/?q=node%2F5 |date=2009-03-05 }}</ref><ref>[http://susanpolgar.blogspot.com/2008/02/chess-records.html Special Chess Records (Susan Polgar)]</ref> Chess players today also avail themselves of computer-based sources of information. {{chess notation|pos=toc}}
==Opening theory== [[File:Lucena1497.jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|right|Early printed work on chess theory by [[Luis Ramirez de Lucena]] c. 1497]] The earliest printed work on chess theory, whose date can be established with some exactitude, is ''Repeticion de Amores y Arte de Ajedrez'' by the [[Spain|Spaniard]] [[Luis Ramirez de Lucena]], published c. 1497, which included among other things analysis of eleven chess openings. Some of them are known today as the [[Giuoco Piano]], [[Ruy Lopez]], [[Petroff's Defense]], [[Bishop's Opening]], [[Damiano Defence|Damiano's Defense]], and [[Scandinavian Defense]], though Lucena did not use those terms.<ref>[[Harry Golombek]], ''Chess: A History'', G.P. Putnam's Sons, 1976, pp. 97-101. {{ISBN|0-399-11575-7}}.</ref>
The authorship and date of the [[Göttingen manuscript]] are not established,<ref name="Murray, p. 782">Murray, p. 782.</ref><ref>Hooper and Whyld, p. 156 ("Göttingen manuscript" entry).</ref> and its publication date is estimated as being somewhere between 1471 and 1505.<ref>Hooper and Whyld, p. 156.</ref> It is not known whether it or Lucena's book was published first.<ref name="Murray, p. 782"/> The manuscript includes examples of games with the openings now known as Damiano's Defence, [[Philidor's Defense]], the Giuoco Piano, Petroff's Defense, the Bishop's Opening, the Ruy Lopez, the [[Ponziani Opening]], the [[Queen's Gambit Accepted]], 1.d4 d5 2.Bf4 Bf5 (a form of the [[London System]]), [[Bird's Opening]], and the [[English Opening]].<ref>Murray, pp. 782-84.</ref> Murray observes that it "is no haphazard collection of commencements of games, but is an attempt to deal with the Openings in a systematic way."<ref>Murray, p. 784.</ref>
Fifteen years after Lucena's book, [[Portugal|Portuguese]] [[apothecary]] [[Pedro Damiano]] published the book ''Questo libro e da imparare giocare a scachi et de la partiti'' (1512) in Rome. It includes analysis of the Queen's Gambit Accepted, showing what happens when Black tries to keep the [[gambit]] [[pawn (chess)|pawn]] with ...b5.<ref>Golombek, pp. 101–02.</ref> Damiano's book "was, in contemporary terms, the first bestseller of the modern game."<ref>Richard Eales, ''Chess: The History of a Game'', Facts on File Publications, 1985, p. 81. {{ISBN|0-8160-1195-8}}.</ref> [[Harry Golombek]] writes that it "ran through eight editions in the sixteenth century and continued on into the next century with unflagging popularity."<ref>Golombek, p. 102.</ref> Modern players know Damiano primarily because his name is attached to the weak opening Damiano's Defense (1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 f6?), although he condemned rather than endorsed it.<ref>Hooper and Whyld, p. 101 ("Damiano Defence" entry).</ref>
These books and later ones discuss games played with various openings, opening traps, and the best way for both sides to play. Certain sequences of opening moves began to be given names, some of the earliest being Damiano's Defense, the [[King's Gambit]] (1.e4 e5 2.f4), the [[Queen's Gambit]] (1.d4 d5 2.c4), and the [[Sicilian Defense]] (1.e4 c5).<ref>Murray, p. 886.</ref>
Damiano's book was followed by general treatises on chess play by [[Ruy López de Segura]] (1561), [[Giulio Cesare Polerio]] (1590), [[Gioachino Greco]] (c. 1625), [[Joseph Bertin]] (1735), and [[François-André Danican Philidor]] (1749).<ref name="I.A. Horowitz, 1964">I.A. Horowitz, ''Chess Openings: Theory and Practice'', Simon and Schuster, 1964.</ref><ref>Hooper and Whyld, pp. 38–39 ("Bertin, Joseph" entry), 157-58 ("Greco, Gioacchino" entry).</ref>
The first author to attempt a comprehensive survey of the openings then known was [[Aaron Alexandre]] in his 1837 work ''Encyclopedie des echecs''.<ref>Hooper and Whyld, pp. 10, 280 ("Alexandre, Aaron" and "openings literature" entries).</ref> According to Hooper and Whyld, "[Carl] [[Carl Jaenisch|Jaenisch]] produced the first openings analysis on modern lines in his ''Analyse nouvelle des ouvertures'' (1842-43)."<ref name="Hooper and Whyld, p. 280">Hooper and Whyld, p. 280.</ref> In 1843, [[Paul Rudolf von Bilguer]] published the German ''[[Handbuch des Schachspiels]]'', which combined the virtues of Alexandre and Jaenisch's works.<ref name="Hooper and Whyld, p. 280"/> The ''Handbuch'', which went through several editions, last being published in several parts in 1912–16, was one of the most important opening references for many decades.<ref>"Bilguer's ''Handbuch'' was the dominant reference for some time until it was superseded by a number of international treatises, which, in the English-speaking world, included ''Modern Chess Openings'' and ''Practical Chess Openings''." I.A. Horowitz, ''Chess Openings: Theory and Practice'', Simon and Schuster, 1964, p. VII. Four years after the first edition of the ''Handbuch'' was published, [[Howard Staunton]] in the preface to ''The Chess-Player's Handbook'', discussed below, called the ''Handbuch'' "a production—whether considered in reference to its research, its suggestiveness, or the methodical completeness of its arrangement—which stands unrivalled and alone". Howard Staunton, ''The Chess-Player's Handbook'', Henry C. Bohn, 1847, p. vii.</ref> The last edition of the ''Handbuch'' was edited by [[Carl Schlechter]], who had drawn a match for the World Championship with [[Emanuel Lasker]] in 1910. [[International Master]] [[William Hartston]] called it "a superb work, perhaps the last to encase successfully the whole of chess knowledge within a single volume."<ref>William Hartston, ''The Kings of Chess'', Harper & Row, 1985, p. 87. {{ISBN|0-06-015358-X}}.</ref>
The [[England|English]] [[master (chess)|master]] [[Howard Staunton]], perhaps the world's strongest player from 1843 to 1851,<ref>Statistician [[Arpad Elo]], developer of the [[Elo rating|Elo rating system]], analyzed the results of all 342 match, tournament, and exhibition games of record among the top nine players in the world from 1846 to 1862. From those games, he estimated the ratings of the top players during that period as 1. [[Paul Morphy]] 2695; 2. [[Adolf Anderssen]] 2552; 3. [[Daniel Harrwitz]] 2518; 4. [[Ignatz Kolisch]] 2516; 5. Staunton 2508. Arpad E. Elo, ''The Rating of Chessplayers, Past and Present'', Arco Publishing, 1978, p. 55–56. {{ISBN|0-668-04721-6}}. Staunton was arguably the strongest player in the world between 1843, when he won a match against the French champion [[Pierre Charles Fournier de Saint-Amant]], and 1851, when he finished fourth in the London 1851 knock-out tournament, won by Anderssen.</ref> included over 300 pages of analysis of the openings in his 1847 treatise ''The Chess Player's Handbook.''<ref>Staunton, pp. 59–401.</ref> That work immediately became the standard reference work in English-speaking countries,<ref>Hooper and Whyld state that it "became the standard reference work in English-speaking countries." Hooper and Whyld, p. 280 ("Openings literature" entry).</ref><ref>Murray states that the book "took rank at once as the leading English text-book on chess." Murray, p. 885.</ref> and was reprinted 21 times by 1935.<ref>Richard Eales, Chess: The History of a Game, Facts on File Publications, 1985, p. 137 (the book "became the standard reference work for English club players down to the end of the century, with twenty-one reprints by 1935"). {{ISBN|0-8160-1195-8}}.</ref> However, "as time passed a demand arose for more up-to-date works in English".<ref name="Whyld p. 280">Hooper and Whyld, p. 280 ("Openings literature" entry).</ref> [[Wilhelm Steinitz]], the first [[World Chess Championship|World Champion]], widely considered the "father of modern chess,"<ref>[[Garry Kasparov]], ''My Great Predecessors, Part I'', Everyman Publishers, 2003, pp. 45–46. {{ISBN|1-85744-330-6}}.</ref><ref>[[Emanuel Lasker]], ''Lasker's Manual of Chess'', Dover Publications, 1960, pp. 188–229. {{ISBN|0-486-20640-8}}.</ref><ref>[[Richard Réti]], ''Masters of the Chessboard'', Dover Publications, 1976, pp. 47–49. {{ISBN|0-486-23384-7}}.</ref><ref>[[Anthony Saidy]], ''The Battle of Chess Ideas'', RHM Press, 1975, pp. 20–21. {{ISBN|0-89058-018-9}}.</ref> extensively analyzed various [[Open Game|double king-pawn openings]] (beginning 1.e4 e5) in his book ''The Modern Chess Instructor'', published in 1889 and 1895.<ref>Wilhelm Steinitz, ''The Modern Chess Instructor'', Edition Olms AG, Zürich, 1990 (reprint). {{ISBN|3-283-00111-1}}.</ref> Also in 1889, [[Edward Freeborough|E. Freeborough]] and the Reverend [[Charles Ranken|C.E. Ranken]] published the first edition of ''Chess Openings Ancient and Modern''; later editions were published in 1893, 1896, and 1910.<ref>[http://www.chessville.com/reviews/ChessOpeningsAncientandModern_and_ChessEndings.htm Review of Chess Openings Ancient & Modern] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081007101938/http://chessville.com/reviews/ChessOpeningsAncientandModern_and_ChessEndings.htm |date=2008-10-07 }}</ref> In 1911, [[Richard Griffith (chess player)|R.C. Griffith]] and [[John Herbert White|J.H. White]] published the first edition of ''[[Modern Chess Openings]]''. It is now the longest-published opening treatise in history; the fifteenth edition (commonly called ''MCO-15''), by [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]] [[Nick de Firmian]], was published in April 2008.<ref>Nick de Firmian, ''Modern Chess Openings, 15th Edition'', McKay Chess Library, 2008. {{ISBN|978-0-8129-3682-7}}.</ref>
According to Hooper and Whyld, the various editions of ''Modern Chess Openings'', the last edition of the ''Handbuch'', and the fourth edition of [[Ludvig Collijn|Ludvig Collijn's]] ''[[Larobok]]'' (in [[Swedish (language)|Swedish]]), with groundbreaking contributions by Rubinstein, Reti, Spielmann and Nimzowitch "were the popular reference sources for strong players between the two [[world wars]]."<ref name="Whyld p. 280"/> In 1937-39 former World Champion [[Max Euwe]] published a twelve-volume opening treatise, ''De theorie der schaakopeningen'', in [[Dutch (language)|Dutch]]. It was later translated into other languages.<ref>Hooper and Whyld, p. 281 ("Openings literature" entry).</ref>
In the late 1930s to early 1950s [[Reuben Fine]], one of the world's strongest players,<ref>Fine tied for first with [[Paul Keres]] at [[AVRO tournament|AVRO 1938]], at the time the strongest tournament ever held, ahead of such players as reigning world champion [[Alexander Alekhine]], former world champion [[José Raúl Capablanca]], and future world champion [[Mikhail Botvinnik]]. After Alekhine's death in 1946, Fine was invited to participate in the match-tournament to select the new champion, but declined in order to pursue his study of [[psychoanalysis]]. "From about 1936 to 1951, when he practically gave up competitive chess, Fine was among the strongest eight players in the world." [[David Hooper (chess player)|David Hooper]] and [[Kenneth Whyld]], ''The Oxford Companion to Chess'', Oxford University Press, 1984, p. 113. {{ISBN|0-19-217540-8}}.</ref> also became one of its leading theoreticians, publishing important works on the opening, middlegame, and endgame. These began with his revision of ''Modern Chess Openings'', which was published in 1939.<ref>R.C. Griffith, J.H. White, Reuben Fine, and P.W. Sergeant, ''Modern Chess Openings'', David McKay (6th ed. 1939).</ref> In 1943, he published ''Ideas Behind the Chess Openings'', which sought to explain the principles underlying the openings.<ref>Reuben Fine, ''Ideas Behind the Chess Openings'', David McKay, 1943.</ref> In 1948, he published his own opening treatise, ''Practical Chess Openings'', a competitor to ''MCO''.<ref>Reuben Fine, ''Practical Chess Openings'', David McKay, 1948.</ref> In 1964, [[International Master]] [[I.A. Horowitz]] published the 789-page tome ''Chess Openings: Theory and Practice'', which in addition to opening analysis includes a large number of illustrative games.<ref name="I.A. Horowitz, 1964"/>
In 1966, the first volume of ''[[Chess Informant]]'' was published in [[Belgrade]], [[Yugoslavia]], containing 466 annotated games from the leading chess tournaments and matches of the day.<ref>''Chess Informant'', Volume 1, [[Belgrade|Beograd]], 1966.</ref> The hugely influential ''Chess Informant'' series has revolutionized opening theory. Its great innovation is that it expresses games in languageless [[algebraic chess notation#Figurine algebraic notation|figurine algebraic notation]] and annotated them using no words, but rather seventeen symbols, whose meanings were explained at the beginning of the book in six different languages. This enabled readers around the world to read the same games and annotations, thus greatly accelerating the dissemination of chess ideas and the development of opening theory. The editors of ''Chess Informant'' later introduced other publications using the same principle, such as the five-volume ''[[Encyclopedia of Chess Openings]]'' and ''Encyclopedia of Chess Endings'' treatises. ''Chess Informant'' was originally published twice a year, and since 1991 has been published thrice annually. Volume 100 was published in 2007.<ref>''Chess Informant'', Volume 100, Šahovski Informator, 2007. ISSN 0351-1375.</ref> It now uses 57 symbols, explained in 10 languages, to annotate games (see [[punctuation (chess)]]), and is available in both print and electronic formats. In 2005, former World Champion [[Garry Kasparov]] wrote, "We are all Children of the ''Informant''."<ref>[http://www.sahovski.co.rs/other/beyond/article47_ws.htm The Best of Chess Informant] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110601231112/http://www.sahovski.co.rs/other/beyond/article47_ws.htm |date=June 1, 2011 }}: Garry Kasparov</ref>
In the 1990s and thereafter, the development of opening theory has been further accelerated by such innovations as extremely strong [[chess engines]] such as [[Fritz (chess)|Fritz]] and [[Rybka]], [[software]] such as [[ChessBase]], and the sale of multi-million-game databases such as ChessBase's Mega 2013 database, with over 5.4 million games.<ref>[http://en.chessbase.com/home/TabId/211/PostId/4008711 The new Mega Database 2013 is shipping] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130712034439/http://en.chessbase.com/home/TabId/211/PostId/4008711 |date=July 12, 2013 }}</ref> Today, the most important openings have been analyzed over 20 moves deep,<ref>For example, various lines of the Botvinnik Variation of the [[Semi-Slav Defense]] (1.d4 d5 2.c4 c6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.Nc3 e6 5.Bg5 dxc4 6.e4 b5 7.e5 h6 8.Bh4 g5 9.Nxg5 hxg5 10.Bxg5 Nbd7) have been analyzed more than 30 moves deep. John Watson, ''Mastering the Chess Openings, Volume 2'', Gambit Publications, 2007, p. 101. {{ISBN|978-1-904600-69-5}}. ''Nunn's Chess Openings'' (1999), a one-volume treatise that does not go into as much detail as more specialized opening manuals, analyzed one line of the Botvinnik Variation to a [[List of chess terms#Draw|draw]] by [[perpetual check]] after 44 moves. [[John Nunn]], [[Graham Burgess]], [[John Emms (chess player)|John Emms]], and [[Joseph Gallagher|Joe Gallagher]], ''Nunn's Chess Openings'', Everyman Publishers, 1999, p. 407 n. 41. {{ISBN|1-85744-221-0}}. [[Vladimir Kramnik]] learned after his game with [[Viswanathan Anand]] at the London Chess Classic 2014, also a Botvinnik Variation, that the first 40 moves of the game had occurred in 10 prior games, all played by computer programs. ''New in Chess'' Magazine 2015, No. 1, p. 34.</ref> sometimes well into the endgame,<ref>GM [[Alexander Kotov]] mentions an instance from the 1950 [[Candidates Tournament]] where GM [[David Bronstein]], "who for years worked closely with [GM Isaac] [[Isaac Boleslavsky|Boleslavsky]]", expressed surprise that the latter was thinking for a long time about his next move in a game against GM [[Gideon Ståhlberg]]. Bronstein remarked that "this position has been analyzed by us far into the end game". Alexander Kotov, "Why the Russians?", ''Chessworld'', January–February 1964, pp. 62–69, at 69. Kotov wrote that the [[Soviet Union|Soviets]] had analyzed many opening variations "far into the end game". ''Id.''</ref><ref>For instance, GM [[Andrew Soltis]] mentions a line in the [[Sicilian Defense#Dragon Variation|Dragon Variation]] of the [[Sicilian Defense]] that begins 1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 d6 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 Nf6 5.Nc3 g6 6.Be3 Bg7 7.f3 Nc6 8.Qd2 0-0 9.Bc4 Nxd4 10.Qxd4 Qa5 11.0-0-0 Be6 12.Bb3 b5 13.Kb1 Rfc8 14.Rhe1! Bxb3 15.cxb3 b4 16.Bxf6! bxc3 17.Bxc3 Bxc3 18.bxc3 Qxc3 19.Qxc3 Rxc3 20.Rc1! Rac8 21.Rxc3 Rxc3 22.Rc1! Rxc1+ 23.Kxc1. Soltis writes that since this position began appearing 30 years ago "it's looked more and more like a forced win for White because he can create an [[outside passed pawn]]. A recent analysis in ''[[New in Chess]]'' concluded that White's win is certain-once you get to move 69." Andrew Soltis, "Chess to Enjoy" column, "The Neutron Bomb Middlegame", ''[[Chess Life]]'', October 2006, p. 10.</ref> and it is not unusual for leading players to introduce [[List of chess terms#Theoretical novelty|theoretical novelties]] on move 25 or even later.<ref>For example, [[John L. Watson]] writes of the [[Ruy Lopez#Marshall Attack|Marshall Attack]] in the [[Ruy Lopez]], "When I opened a book on the Marshall Attack ... I learned that for the 'old main line' (which is still extremely popular), 'the real struggle begins around move 30'! And in fact, [[correspondence chess]] games sometimes take it a step further, with one side playing a new move as the endgame begins!" John Watson, ''Mastering the Chess Openings, Volume 1'', Gambit Publications, 2006, pp. 161–62. {{ISBN|978-1-904600-60-2}}.</ref><ref>In [http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1542350 Shulman–Marin, Reykjavik Open 2009], [[Mihail Marin|Marin]] played a theoretical novelty on move 34 in the [[Exchange Variation]] of the [[Grünfeld Defense]]. ''[[Chess Informant]]'', ''1000 TN!! The Best Theoretical Novelties'', 2012, pp. 579–80.</ref><ref>In the [[Sicilian Defense#Sveshnikov Variation: 4...Nf6 5.Nc3 e5|Sveshnikov Variation]] of the [[Sicilian Defense]], another heavily analyzed line, the game O. Korneev–M. Devereaux, [[Port Erin]] 2006, featured a theoretical novelty on Black's 29th move, improving on a previous high-level game [[Veselin Topalov|Topalov]]–[[Peter Leko|Leko]], [[Linares chess tournament|Linares]] 2005. John Cox, ''Starting Out: Sicilian Sveshnikov'', Gloucester Publishers, 2007, pp. 118–23. {{ISBN|978-1-85744-431-5}}. See [http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1333272 Topalov-Leko, Linares 2005]; [http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1434853 Korneev-Devereaux, Port Erin 2006].</ref>
Thousands of books have been written on chess openings. These include both comprehensive openings encyclopedias such as the ''Encyclopedia of Chess Openings'' and ''Modern Chess Openings''; general treatises on how to play the opening such as ''Mastering the Chess Openings'' (in four volumes), by International Master [[John L. Watson]];<ref>''Mastering the Chess Openings, Volume 1'', cited above.</ref> and myriad books on specific openings, such as ''Understanding the Grünfeld''<ref>[[Jonathan Rowson]], ''Understanding the Grünfeld'', Gambit Publications, 1999. {{ISBN|1-901983-09-9}}.</ref> and ''Chess Explained: The Classical Sicilian''.<ref>[[Alex Yermolinsky]], ''Chess Explained: The Classical Sicilian'', Gambit Publications, 2006. {{ISBN|1-904600-42-5}}.</ref> "Books and monographs on openings are popular, and as they are thought to become out of date quickly there is a steady supply of new titles."<ref>Hooper and Whyld, p. 230 ("literature of chess" entry).</ref> According to [[Andrew Soltis]], "Virtually all the new information about chess since 1930 has been in the opening."<ref>Andrew Soltis, "Tools of the Trade . . .", ''[[Chess Life]]'', July 1995, p. 14.</ref>
==Middlegame theory== [[File:Aron Nimzowitsch.jpg|thumb|144px|right|Aron Nimzowitsch]] Middlegame theory is considerably less developed than either opening theory or endgame theory.<ref>Watson, ''Secrets of Modern Chess Strategy, p. 10.</ref> Watson writes, "Players wishing to study this area of the game have a limited and rather unsatisfactory range of resources from which to choose."<ref name="Modern Chess Strategy p. 10">''Secrets of Modern Chess Strategy'', p. 10.</ref>
One of the earliest theories to gain attention was that of [[William Steinitz]], who posited that a premature attack against one's opponent in an equal position could be repelled by skillful defence, and so a player's best bet was to slowly maneuver with the goal of accumulating small advantages. Emanuel Lasker in ''Lasker's Manual of Chess'' and Max Euwe in ''The Development of Chess Style'' outlined theories that they attributed to Steinitz.
Leading player and theorist [[Aron Nimzowitsch|Aron Nimzowitsch's]]<ref>GM [[Raymond Keene]] writes that Nimzowitsch "was one of the world's leading Grandmasters for a period extending over a quarter of a century, and for some of that time he was the obvious challenger for the world championship. ... [He was also] a great and profound chess thinker, second only to Steinitz, and his works—''Die Blockade'', ''My System'' and ''Chess Praxis''--established his reputation as one of the father figures of modern chess." Keene, ''Aron Nimzowitsch: A Reappraisal'', David McKay, 1974, p. 1. {{ISBN|0-679-13040-3}}.</ref> influential books, ''[[My System]]'' (1925),<ref>Aron Nimzowitsch, ''My System (21st Century Edition)'', Hays Publishing, 1991. {{ISBN|1-880673-85-1}}. Aron Nimzovich, ''My System'', David McKay, 1947, {{ISBN|0-679-14025-5}}.</ref> ''Die [[List of chess terms#Blockade|Blockade]]'' (1925) (in [[German (language)|German]]),<ref>Aron Nimzowitsch, ''Blockade'' (English translation), Chess Enterprises, 1980. {{ISBN|0-931462-07-X}}.</ref> and ''Chess Praxis'' (1936),<ref>Aron Nimzowitsch, ''Chess Praxis (21st Century Edition)'', Hays Publishing, 1993. {{ISBN|1-880673-91-6}}.</ref><ref>Aron Nimzovich, ''Chess Praxis: The Praxis of My System'', Dover Publications, 1962. SBN 486-20296-8.</ref> are among the most important works on the middlegame.<ref name="Modern Chess Strategy p. 10"/> Nimzowitsch called attention to the possibility of letting one's opponent occupy the centre with pawns while you exert control with your pieces as in the Nimzo-Indian or Queen's Indian defences. He pointed out how in positions with interlocking pawn chains, one could attack the chain at its base by advancing one's own pawns and carrying out a freeing move (pawn break). He also drew attention to the strategy of occupying open files with one's rooks in order to later penetrate to the seventh rank where they could attack the enemy pawns and hem in the opponent's king. Another of his key concepts was prophylaxis, moves aimed at limiting the opponent's mobility to the point where he would no longer have any useful moves.
In 1952, Fine published the 442-page ''The Middle Game in Chess'', perhaps the most comprehensive treatment of the subject up until that time.<ref>Reuben Fine, ''The Middle Game in Chess'', David McKay, 1952.</ref> The mid-20th century also saw the publication of ''The Middle Game'', volumes 1 and 2, by former World Champion [[Max Euwe]] and Hans Kramer,<ref>Dr. M. Euwe and H. Kramer, ''The Middle Game, Book One: Static Features'', G. Bell and Sons, 1964. {{ISBN|0-7135-0431-5}}.</ref><ref>Dr. M. Euwe and H. Kramer, ''The Middle Game, Book Two: Dynamic and Subjective Features'', G. Bell and Sons, 1965. {{ISBN|0-7135-0432-3}}.</ref> and a series of books by the [[Czechoslovakia|Czechoslovak]]-German grandmaster [[Luděk Pachman]]: three volumes of ''Complete [[Chess strategy|Chess Strategy]]'',<ref>Luděk Pachman, ''Complete Chess Strategy, Volume 1: First Principles of the Middle Game'', Cornerstone Library, 1975. {{ISBN|0-346-12321-6}}.</ref><ref>Luděk Pachman, ''Complete Chess Strategy, Volume 2: Principles of [[Pawn (chess)|Pawn]] Play and the [[List of chess terms#Center|Center]]'', Cornerstone Library, 1976. {{ISBN|0-346-12343-7}}.</ref><ref>Luděk Pachman, ''Complete Chess Strategy: Play on the [[List of chess terms#W|Wings]]'', David McKay, 1978. {{ISBN|0-679-13252-X}}.</ref> ''Modern Chess Strategy'',<ref>Luděk Pachman, ''Modern Chess Strategy'', Dover Publications, 1971. {{ISBN|0-486-20290-9}}.</ref> ''Modern [[Chess tactics|Chess Tactics]]'',<ref>Luděk Pachman, ''Modern Chess Tactics'', Routledge & Kegan Paul Ltd, 1972. {{ISBN|0-7100-7098-5}}.</ref> and ''[[List of chess terms#Attack|Attack]] and [[List of chess terms#Defence|Defense]] in Modern Chess Tactics''.<ref>Luděk Pachman, ''Attack and Defense in Modern Chess Tactics'', David McKay, 1973.</ref>
Another key turning point in middlegame theory came with the release of Alexander Kotov's book ''Think like a Grandmaster'' in 1971. Kotov outlined how a player calculates by developing a tree of variations in his head, and recommended that players only examine each branch of the tree once. He also noted how some players seem to fall victim to what is now known as Kotov's Syndrome: they calculate out a large range of different lines, become dissatisfied with the result, and realizing that they are short on time, play a completely new candidate move without even checking whether it is sound. More recently, Jonathan Tisdall, John Nunn and Andrew Soltis have elaborated on Kotov's tree theory further.
In 1999, Watson's ''Secrets of Modern Chess Strategy: Advances Since Nimzowitsch'' was published, in which Watson discusses the revolution in middlegame theory that has occurred since Nimzowitsch's time.<ref>''Secrets of Modern Chess Strategy'', pp. 10-13.</ref>
There are also many books on specific aspects of the middlegame, such as ''The Art of Attack in Chess'' by [[Vladimir Vuković]],<ref>V. Vuković, ''The Art of Attack in Chess'', Pergamon Press, 1965. {{ISBN|0-08-011196-3}}.</ref> ''The Art of [[Sacrifice (chess)|Sacrifice]] in Chess'' by [[Rudolf Spielmann]],<ref>Rudolf Spielmann, ''The Art of Sacrifice in Chess'', David McKay, 1951.</ref> ''The Art of the [[Checkmate]]'' by Georges Renaud and Victor Kahn,<ref>Georges Renaud and Victor Kahn, ''The Art of the Checkmate'', Dover Publications, 1962. {{ISBN|0-486-20106-6}}.</ref> ''The Basis of [[Combination (chess)|Combination]] in Chess'' by J. du Mont,<ref>J. du Mont, ''The Basis of Combination in Chess'', Dover Publications, 1978. {{ISBN|0-486-23644-7}}.</ref> and ''The Art of Defense in Chess'' by [[Andrew Soltis]].<ref>Andrew Soltis, ''The Art of Defense in Chess'', David McKay, 1975. {{ISBN|0-679-13043-8}}.</ref>
==Endgame theory== Many significant chess treatises, beginning with the earliest works, have included some analysis of the endgame. Lucena's book (c. 1497) concluded with 150 examples of endgames and [[chess problem]]s.<ref>Golombek, p. 101.</ref>
The second edition (1777) of Philidor's ''Analyse du jeu des Échecs'' devoted 75 pages of analysis to various endgames.<ref>François-André Danican Philidor, ''Analysis of the Game of Chess'', Hardinge Simpole, 2005 (reprint), pp. 230-304. {{ISBN|1-84382-161-3}}.</ref> These included a number of theoretically important endings, such as rook and bishop versus rook, queen versus rook, queen versus rook and pawn, and rook and pawn versus rook. Certain positions in the endings of rook and bishop versus rook, rook and pawn versus rook, and queen versus rook have become known as [[Philidor position|Philidor's position]]. Philidor concluded his book with two pages of (in the English translation), "Observations on the ends of parties", in which he set forth certain general principles about endings, such as: "Two knights alone cannot mate" (see [[two knights endgame]]), the ending with a bishop and rook pawn whose queening square is on the opposite color from the bishop is drawn (see [[wrong rook pawn#Bishop and pawn]]), and a queen beats a bishop and knight (see [[pawnless chess endgame#Queen versus two minor pieces]]).<ref>Philidor, pp. 305-06.</ref>
Staunton's ''The Chess-Player's Handbook'' (1847) includes almost 100 pages of analysis of endgames.<ref>Howard Staunton, ''The Chess-Player's Handbook'', Henry G. Bohn, 1847, pp. 403-500. Some of Staunton's analysis, such as his analysis of the very rare rook versus three minor pieces endgame, is surprisingly sophisticated. At page 439, he wrote, "Three minor Pieces are much stronger than a Rook, and in cases where two of them are Bishops will usually win without much difficulty, because the player of the Rook is certain to be compelled to lose him for one of his adversary's Pieces. If, however, there are two Knights and one Bishop opposed to a Rook, the latter may generally be [[Exchange (chess)|exchanged]] for the Bishop, and as two Knights are insufficient of themselves to force checkmate, the game will be drawn." Modern-day [[endgame tablebase]]s confirm Staunton's assessments of both endings. [[Karsten Müller]] and [[Frank Lamprecht]], ''Fundamental Chess Endings'', Gambit Publications, 2001, p. 403. {{ISBN|1-901983-53-6}}. Yet Reuben Fine, 94 years after Staunton, erroneously wrote on page 521 of ''[[Basic Chess Endings]]'' that both types of rook versus three minor piece endings "are theoretically drawn." Grandmaster [[Pal Benko]], an authority on the endgame and like Fine a world-class player at his peak, perpetuated Fine's error in his 2003 revision of ''Basic Chess Endings''. Reuben Fine and Pal Benko, ''Basic Chess Endings (Algebraic Edition)'', McKay Chess Library, 2003, p. 524, {{ISBN|0-8129-3493-8}}. Grandmaster [[Andrew Soltis]] in a 2004 book expressly disagreed with Staunton, claiming that the rook versus two bishops and knight ending is drawn with correct play. Andrew Soltis, ''rethinking the chess pieces'', Batsford 2004, p. 84. {{ISBN|0-7134-8904-9}}. At the time Benko and Soltis offered their assessments (in 2003 and 2004, respectively), endgame tablebases had already proven that Staunton was correct, and that Fine, Benko, and Soltis were wrong, although the ending can take up to 68 moves to win. Müller and Lamprecht, p. 403.
Staunton's conclusions on these endgames were, however, anticipated by the British master [[George Walker (chess player)|George Walker]], who wrote in 1846 (and perhaps earlier):<blockquote>Although the two Bishops and Kt win, as a general proposition, against Rook, yet the two Knights with a Bishop cannot expect the same success; and the legitimate result of such conflict would be a draw. The Bishops, united, are stronger than the Knights, as they strike from a greater distance. When the two Knights are left with a Bishop, the Rook has also the chance of exchanging for the latter, which can hardly be avoided by his adversary, and the two Knights, alone, have not the mating power.</blockquote> George Walker, ''The Art of Chess-Play: A New Treatise on the Game of Chess'' (4th ed. 1846), Sherwood, Gilbert, & Piper, p. 254.</ref>
In 1941 Reuben Fine published his monumental 573-page treatise ''Basic Chess Endings'', the first attempt at a comprehensive treatise on the endgame.<ref>Reuben Fine, ''Basic Chess Endings'', David McKay, 1941.</ref> A new edition, revised by [[Pal Benko]], was published in 2003.<ref>Reuben Fine and Pal Benko, ''Basic Chess Endings'', Random House, 2003. {{ISBN|0-8129-3493-8}}.</ref> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Averbakh1950s.JPG|left|150px|thumb|Yuri Averbakh in the 1950s]] --> [[USSR|Soviet]] writers published an important series of books on specific endings: ''Rook Endings'' by [[Grigory Levenfish]] and [[Vasily Smyslov]],<ref>Grigory Levenfish and Vasily Smyslov, ''Rook Endings'', Chess Digest, 1971. {{ISBN|0-7134-0354-3}}.</ref> ''Pawn Endings'' by [[Yuri Averbakh]] and I. Maizelis,<ref>Y. Averbakh and I. Maizelis, ''Pawn Endings'', Chess Digest, 1974.</ref> ''Queen and Pawn Endings'' by Averbakh,<ref>Yuri Averbakh, ''Queen and Pawn Endings'', Chess Digest, 1975, {{ISBN|0-7134-3041-9}}.</ref> ''Bishop Endings'' by Averbakh,<ref>Yuri Averbakh, ''Bishop Endings'', Batsford, 1977. {{ISBN|0-7134-0096-X}}.</ref> ''Knight Endings'' by Averbakh and [[Vitaly Chekhover]],<ref>Yuri Averbakh and Vitaly Chekhover, ''Knight Endings'', Batsford 1977. {{ISBN|0-7134-0552-X}}.</ref> ''Bishop v. Knight Endings'' by Yuri Averbakh,<ref>Yuri Averbakh, ''Bishop v. Knight Endings'', Batsford, 1976. {{ISBN|0-7134-3179-2}}.</ref> ''Rook v. Minor Piece Endings'' by Averbakh,<ref>Yuri Averbakh, ''Rook v. Minor Piece Endings'', Batsford, 1978. {{ISBN|0-7134-0868-5}}.</ref> and ''Queen v. Rook/Minor Piece Endings'' by Averbakh, Chekhover, and V. Henkin.<ref>Yuri Averbakh, V. Chekhover, and V. Henkin, ''Queen v. Rook/Minor Piece Endings'', Batsford, 1978. {{ISBN|0-7134-0866-9}}.</ref> These books by Averbakh and others were collected into the five-volume ''Comprehensive Chess Endings'' in English.
In recent years, computer-generated [[endgame tablebase]]s have revolutionized endgame theory, conclusively showing [[Perfect play|best play]] in many complicated endgames that had vexed human analysts for over a century, such as [[queen (chess)|queen]] and pawn versus queen. They have also overturned human theoreticians' verdicts on a number of endgames; for example by proving that the two [[bishop (chess)|bishops]] versus [[knight (chess)|knight]] ending, which had been thought drawn for over a century, can be a win for the bishops (see [[pawnless chess endgame#Minor pieces only]] and [[Chess endgame#Effect of tablebases on endgame theory]]).
Several important works on the endgame have been published in recent years, among them ''Dvoretsky's Endgame Manual'',<ref>Mark Dvoretsky, ''Dvoretsky's Endgame Manual (second Edition)'', Russell Enterprises, 2006. {{ISBN|1-888690-19-4}}.</ref> ''Fundamental Chess Endings'' by [[Karsten Müller]] and [[Frank Lamprecht]],<ref>Karsten Muller and Frank Lamprecht, ''Fundamental Chess Endings'', Gambit Publications, 2001. {{ISBN|1-901983-53-6}}.</ref> ''Basic Endgames: 888 Theoretical Positions'' by [[Yuri Balashov]] and Eduard Prandstetter,<ref>Yuri Balashov and Eduard Prandstetter, ''Basic Endgames'', Prague Chess Agency, 1992. {{ISBN|80-901056-0-2}}.</ref> ''Chess Endgame Lessons'' by Benko,<ref>Pal Benko, ''Chess Endgame Lessons'', 1989, Library of Congress Catalogue No. 89-64215.</ref> and ''Secrets of Rook Endings''<ref>John Nunn, ''Secrets of Rook Endings'', Henry Holt, 1993. {{ISBN|0-8050-2640-1}}.</ref> and ''Secrets of Pawnless Endings'' by [[John Nunn]].<ref>John Nunn, ''Secrets of Pawnless Endings'', Henry Holt, 1994. {{ISBN|0-8050-3285-1}}.</ref> Some of these have been aided by analysis from endgame tablebases.
==See also== * [[List of chess openings]] * [[Chess endgame literature]] * [[Chess piece relative value]]
==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Chess}}
[[Category:Chess theory| ]] [[Category:Chess terminology]]

{{coord|42.814957|-75.542754|display=title}} {{Infobox_Stadium | stadium_name = Wesley M. Cotterell Court| nickname = Adonal's House| image = Cotterell Court.jpg | location = 13 Oak Drive
Hamilton, NY 13346| coordinates = | broke_ground = | opened = 1959| renovated = 2001| closed = | demolished = | owner = Colgate University| operator = Colgate University| surface = Hardwood| construction_cost= | architect = | former_names = | tenants = Colgate University Raiders
(men's and women's basketball and volleyball)| seating_capacity = 1,750 (basketball & volleyball)| }} '''Cotterell Court''' is a 1,750-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Hamilton (village), New York|Hamilton, New York]]. It was built in 1959 and is home to the [[Colgate University]] Raiders [[basketball]] and [[volleyball]] [[team]]s. It is named for Wesley M. Cotterell '19, a two-time letterwinner in basketball and school trustee. The basketball arena was built as the northern half of the William A. Reid Athletic Center, a twin barrel-vaulted complex which also houses [[Starr Arena|Starr Rink]]. The complex is located on the western side of campus next to [[Andy Kerr Stadium]] and across Broad Street from Huntington Gymnasium, the school's former athletics facility. It was renovated in 2000-2001. The gym has bleacher seating on three sides, with the main sides being the east and west sides and a much shorter section on the north side. The main entrance to the arena is on the south side, leading into the rest of the athletic center. It hosted the 1996 [[Patriot League]] men's basketball tournament final. On November 4, 1977 the [[Grateful Dead]] played here as the homecoming weekend headliners. Similarly, [[The Doors]] and [[Bob Marley]] have played here, as well as [[Phish]], who headlined Spring Party Weekend on April 23, 1993. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.gocolgateraiders.com/sports/2005/12/13/cotterell.aspx Colgate University Athletics - Cotterell Court] {{Colgate Raiders men's basketball navbox}} {{Colgate Raiders women's basketball navbox}} {{Patriot League basketball venue navbox}} [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Colgate Raiders basketball]] [[Category:Basketball venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in New York (state)]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues in Madison County, New York]] [[Category:1959 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1959]] [[Category:College volleyball venues in the United States]] {{NewYork-sports-venue-stub}}
