revision.comment: /* NBA steals records */ a lot of really ticky-tacky stats and arbitrary cutoffs about number of seasons with xyz s/g, this should be just a brief list of absolutes - most in a game/season/career are indisputably worthy of inclusion, the others can be found on many sports stats websites devoted to this type of thing
revision.text:
In [[basketball]], a '''steal''' occurs when a defensive player legally causes a [[turnover (basketball)|turnover]] by his positive, aggressive action(s).<ref name="FIBA Manual">{{cite web | url=http://www.fiba.com/asp_includes/download.asp?file_id=554 | title=FIBA Statistics Manual 2005 | accessdate=March 9, 2011 | author=[[FIBA]] | pages=43, 44}}</ref><ref name="NCAA Manual">{{cite web | url=http://fs.ncaa.org/Docs/stats/Stats_Manuals/Basketball/2011EZ.pdf | title=NCAA Official Basketball Statistician's Manual | accessdate=March 9, 2011 |author1=Isaacs, David |author2=Johnson, Gary K. | pages=10, 11}}</ref> This can be done by deflecting and controlling, or by catching the opponent's pass or [[Dribble#Basketball|dribble]] of an offensive player. The defender must not touch the offensive player's hands or otherwise a ''[[foul (basketball)|foul]]'' is called.
Steals are credited to the defensive player who first causes the turnover, even if he does not end up with possession of the live ball. To earn a steal, the defensive player must be the initiator of the action causing the turnover, not just the benefactor.<ref name="FIBA Manual" /><ref name="NCAA Manual" /> Whenever a steal is recorded by a defensive player, an offensive player must be credited as committing a turnover.
Stealing the ball requires good anticipation, speed and fast reflexes, all common traits of good defenders. However, like [[Block (basketball)|blocked shots]], steals are not always a perfect gauge of a player's defensive abilities. An unsuccessful steal can result in the defender being out of position and unable to recover in time, allowing the offense to score. Therefore, attempting to steal is a gamble. Steals, though risky, can pay off greatly, because they often trigger a [[fastbreak]] for the defensive team.
There is no prototypical position from which a player may get many steals. While smaller, quicker [[point guard|guards]] tend to accumulate the most steals, there are many exceptions. For example, forward [[Rick Barry]] led the [[NBA]] in steals in 1974-75, and for many years [[basketball center|center]] [[Hakeem Olajuwon]] led his team in the category, consistently ranking among the league's leaders, and is the only center ranked in the top 10 [[List of National Basketball Association career steals leaders|all-time in steals]]. [[Karl Malone]], a [[Power Forward (basketball)|power forward]], is currently number ten.
==NBA steals records==
Steals were first recorded in the NBA in the [[1973–74 NBA season|1973–74 season]], while the rival [[American Basketball Association|ABA]] league first recorded steals during the same season.
[[Kendall Gill]] and [[Larry Kenon]] are tied for most steals in a regular season NBA game with eleven. Kenon's was recorded on December 26, 1976<ref>{{cite web|title=San Antonio Spurs at Kansas City Kings Box Score, December 26, 1976|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/boxscores/197612260KCK.html}}</ref> while Gill recorded his on April 3, 1999.<ref>{{cite web|title=NBA Single Game Leaders and Records for Steals|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/leaders/stl_game.html}}</ref>
The most steals by a player in an NBA season is 301 by [[Alvin Robertson]] in 1985-86.<ref>{{cite web|title=NBA & ABA Single Season Leaders and Records for Steals|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/leaders/stl_season.html}}</ref>
The NBA's all-time leader for steals is [[John Stockton]] with 3,265 in his career.<ref>{{cite web|title=NBA & ABA Career Leaders and Records for Steals|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/leaders/stl_career.html}}</ref>
The NBA leader in steals per game (SPG) is Robertson with an average of 2.71 (career, 1250 steals minimum)<ref>{{cite web|title=NBA & ABA Career Leaders and Records for Steals Per Game|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/leaders/stl_per_g_career.html}}</ref> and 3.67 (season, 125 minimum).<ref>{{cite web|title=NBA & ABA Single Season Leaders and Records for Steals Per Game|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/leaders/stl_per_g_season.html}}</ref>
[[Baron Davis]] is the all-time playoff leader in steals per game for a career with 2.28 SPG.<ref>{{cite web|title=NBA & ABA Career Playoff Leaders and Records for Steals Per Game|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/leaders/stl_per_g_career_p.html}}</ref>
[[Maurice Cheeks]] in the [[1979 NBA Playoffs|1979 Playoffs]] averaged a playoff record 4.11 SPG.<ref>{{cite web|title=NBA & ABA Single Season Playoff Leaders and Records for Steals Per Game|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/leaders/stl_per_g_season_p.html}}</ref>
==Notable players in the NBA== Some of the greatest defensive specialists in the steals category in the NBA include: * [[Hakeem Olajuwon]]  - ranking in the top 10 All-Time in both steals and blocks. * [[Walt Frazier]] – renowned for his masterful defense, which culminated around his ability to deflect dribbling and passes using his incredibly quick hands. Steals were not recorded during the early part of his career. Frazier once made 8 consecutive steals during a third quarter against Atlanta in 1971.{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} * [[Allen Iverson]] – led the league in steals three times (consecutively); most steals in a playoff game. * [[Michael Jordan]] – led the league in steals and steals per game three times, #3 all-time in career steals and #3 all-time in steals per game. #2 all-time in career steals in the playoffs behind Scottie Pippen. * [[Chris Paul]] – holds the NBA record for most consecutive games with a steal, led the league in steals and steals per game six times. * [[Michael Ray Richardson]] – led the league in steals three times; #2 all-time in steals per game. * [[Alvin Robertson]] – led the league in steals and steals per game three times, #9 [[List of National Basketball Association career steals leaders|all-time in career steals]] and #1 all-time in steals per game. * [[John Stockton]] – led the league in steals twice, #1 all-time in career steals and #6 in steals per game. * [[Jerry West]] – is widely known for his ability to execute steals, but the statistic was not recorded until his final season. West was the first player to officially record [[List of National Basketball Association players with most steals in a game|10 steals in a game]]. * [[Clyde Drexler]] – Drexler had 2,207 steals in his 15-year career with the [[Portland Trail Blazers]] and [[Houston Rockets]]. He is #7 [[List of National Basketball Association career steals leaders|all-time in career steals]].
==See also== *[[List of National Basketball Association career steals leaders]] *[[List of National Basketball Association season steals leaders]] *[[List of National Basketball Association players with most steals in a game]]

page.title: The Dark Side: Secrets of the Sports Dopers

revision.text:
{{Update|date=October 2016}} {{italic title}} '''''The Dark Side: Secrets of the Sports Dopers''''' is a documentary episode of [[Al Jazeera Investigates]] released by [[Al Jazeera English]] and [[Al Jazeera America]] which investigated professional athletes' potential use of [[Performance-enhancing drugs]] (PEDs) naming [[Peyton Manning]] and other prominent athletes like [[Ryan Howard]], [[Ryan Zimmerman]], [[James Harrison (American football)|James Harrison]], and [[Clay Matthews III]].
==Content== On December 27, 2015, Al Jazeera English and Al Jazeera America released a report conducted by the Al Jazeera Investigative Unit called ''The Dark Side: Secrets of the Sports Dopers'' which investigated professional athletes' potential use of [[Performance-enhancing drugs]] (PEDs) naming several prominent athletes as having received drugs from Charles Sly, a pharmacist who had worked at the Guyer Anti-Aging Clinic in Indianapolis during the fall of 2011. The report involved Liam Collins, a British hurdler, going undercover in an attempt to obtain banned substances from Sly and other medical professionals. The report claimed that Manning's wife, Ashley, had been shipped [[Off-label use|off-label]] [[Growth hormone|human growth hormone]] (HGH) by the Guyer Institute during the fall of 2011 while Manning was out with a severe neck injury, with the intention of hiding that Manning was the one actually receiving the drugs; as well as several other athletes been provided the banned hormone supplement Delta-2. Moreover, Sly spoke with great acknowledge about doping and tossed out several athletes like Howard, Zimmerman, Manning and fellow football players [[Mike Neal]] and [[Dustin Keller]].<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/12/dark-side-secrets-sports-dopers-151227133355144.html |title=The dark side: The secret world of sports doping |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/14441114/documentary-links-peyton-manning-other-pro-athletes-use-peds |title=Documentary links Peyton Manning, other pro athletes to use of PEDs |website=[[ESPN.com]] |date=2013-05-01 |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2015/12/29/al-jazeera-reporter-stresses-that-no-allegation-is-being-made-against-peyton-manning/ |title=Al Jazeera reporter stresses that no allegation is being made against Peyton Manning | ProFootballTalk |website=[[Pro Football Talk]] |date= |accessdate=2016-02-08}}</ref>
Sly said on a hidden camera record: {{quote|I did part of my training at the Guyer Institute, which is this anti-aging clinic in Indiana. Him and his wife would come in after hours and get IVs and shit. So one thing that Guyer does is he dispenses drugs out of his office, which physicians can do in the United States. It’s just not very many of them do it. And all the time we would be sending Ashley Manning drugs. Like growth hormone, all the time, everywhere, Florida. And it would never be under Peyton’s name. it would always be under her name. We were sending it everywhere... it’d go to Florida... Almost all drugs you can prescribe off-label. GH is one of the few drugs, it’s really the only drug you cannot prescribe off-label. It has three indications.
[About Guyer] I know for a fact he does. I would see patients with him part of the day and the other part of the day I would work in his pseudo-pharmacy. I’m surprised his place has not been shut down yet.<ref>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/peyton-manning-human-growth-hormone_us_567f16e4e4b0b958f6599440?</ref>}}
[[MLB]] player [[Taylor Teagarden]] also claimed in an undercover footage included in the documentary: {{quote|I used it last year, I was very ... I was scared to be honest with you. I took it for like two weeks and I had a test four weeks after my last administration of it. Nothing happened ... And I was also taking peptides too but they were all urine tests, no blood tests ... Once a year, maybe twice at most.<ref>http://www.cbssports.com/mlb/eye-on-baseball/25538782</ref>}}
==Reactions== Manning told [[ESPN]]'s [[Lisa Salters]] about the reports, on an interview on the morning of the 27th for ESPN [[Sunday NFL Countdown]]: {{quote|“Disgusted is how I feel. Sickened by it. I’m not sure I understand how someone can make something up about somebody, admit he’s made it up and yet somehow it gets published in a story. I don’t understand that. Maybe you can explain it to me, somebody else can. It’s completely fabricated, complete trash, garbage. It makes me sick it brings Ashley into it. Her medical history, her medical privacy being violated. That makes me sick. I don’t understand that. It’s not right. I don’t understand it.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadspin.com/peyton-manning-responds-to-forthcoming-hgh-allegations-1749843040|title=Peyton Manning Appears On ESPN To Refute "Garbage" HGH Claims That Haven't Aired Yet [UPDATE]|author=Timothy Burke|work=[[Deadspin]]|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref>}} Salters pointed other cases have been seen in which athletes deny first and then eventually admit allegations and Manning answered he can't speak for others and he know how hard he worked.<ref name="denvbron">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.denverbroncos.com/news-and-blogs/article-1/Transcript-Peyton-Manning-interviews-with-ESPNs-Lisa-Salters/f07ef954-bada-42fc-ab64-f9f38dc9fb49 |title=Transcript: Peyton Manning interviews with ESPN's Lisa Salters |website=Denverbroncos.com |date= |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref> Nevertheless, Manning also stated he had visited the Guyer Institute 35 times during 2011 and that he had received both medication and treatment from Guyer during this time.<ref name="denvbron"/> Sly recanted his story and requested the report not to be aired via a YouTube video following the release of the report.<ref>{{cite web|author=Sports |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/charlie-sly-recants-statements-about-peyton-manning-2015-12 |title=Charlie Sly recants statements about Peyton Manning |publisher=[[Business Insider]] |date= |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Cleary |first=Tom |url=http://heavy.com/sports/2015/12/charles-charlie-sly-pharmacist-gave-peyton-manning-hgh-human-growth-hormone-texas-indiana-youtube-photos-al-jazeera-documentary-howard-zimmerman-james-harrison/ |title=Charlie Sly: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know |website=[[Heavy.com]] |date= |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref>
Manning took response and hired former [[Presidency of George W. Bush|George W. Bush]] press secretary [[Ari Fleischer]] to manage the issue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/eye-on-football/25427627/report-manning-hires-crisis-manager-ari-fleischer-in-wake-of-hgh-documentary|title=Report: Peyton Manning turns to Ari Fleischer in wake of HGH doc|work=[[CBSSports.com]]|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> He also threatened to sue Al Jazeera but then backed up.<ref>https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/columnist/brennan/2016/05/25/peyton-manning-hgh-allegations-al-jazeera/84922710/</ref> Later, Fleischer confirmed that Ashley Manning did receive shipments from the Guyer Institute, but refused to confirm if the shipments had included HGH.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/14718227/peyton-manning-legal-team-looked-al-jazeera-documentary |title=Peyton Manning's legal team looked into Al Jazeera documentary |website=ESPN.com |date= |accessdate=2016-02-08}}</ref>
Media reactions were varied.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/peyton-manning-al-jazeera-espn_us_568e6d74e4b0cad15e638886|title=Here’s Why ESPN Didn’t Break The Peyton Manning Story|website=[[The Huffington Post]]}}</ref> [[Fox News]]' contributor [[Jesse Watters]] claimed on ''[[The O'Reilly Factor]]'' the PED allegations reported by Al Jazeera were a plot to go "after American icons and US institutions," citing the allegations against Manning as the prime example.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nomorecocktails.com/post/2015/12/28/Jesse-Watters-Is-Al-Jazeera-Going-After-American-Icons-and-US-Institutions-with-Manning-Report.aspx |title=Jesse Watters: Is Al Jazeera ‘Going After American Icons and U.S. Institutions’ with Manning Report? |website=[[Fox News]] |date=2015-12-28 |accessdate=2016-02-08}}</ref> [[NBC News]] on ''[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]'' gave Al Jazeera's reporter Deborah Davies space to specify details about the reports and provide Al Jazeera's version of the story.<ref>{{cite web|author=Tom Ley |url=http://deadspin.com/al-jazeera-reporter-defends-peyton-manning-hgh-report-o-1750120420 |title=Al Jazeera Reporter Defends Peyton Manning HGH Report On Today Show |website=Deadspin |date=2015-12-29 |accessdate=2016-02-08}}</ref> [[CNN]]'s ''[[Reliable Sources]]'' with [[Brian Stelter]] reported Al Jazeera was in contact with a second source who confirmed that the clinic sent HGH to Ashley Manning in Florida and elsewhere, and according to Davies was “absolutely impeccably placed, knowledgeable and credible”.<ref>{{cite web|author=Timothy Burke |url=http://deadspin.com/al-jazeera-reporter-second-knowledgable-and-credible-1750778458 |title=Al Jazeera Reporter: Second "Knowledgable And Credible" Source Confirms HGH Sent To Manning House |website=Deadspin |date= |accessdate=2016-02-08}}</ref> After Salters' interview with Manning, former [[NFL]] coach and ESPN pundit [[Mike Ditka]] expressed on the same Sunday NFL Countdown episode: “Al Jazeera is not a credible news organization. They’re out there spreading garbage.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/football/ditka-takes-heat-al-jazeera-not-credible-article-1.2478031|title=Ditka takes heat for saying Al Jazeera is 'not credible'|author=SCOTT CHIUSANO|date=27 December 2015|work=[[NY Daily News]]|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' sportswriter and ''[[NBC Sunday Night Football]]'' contributor [[Peter King (sportswriter)|Peter King]] called Al Jazeera on his column ''The MMQB'' a day later "a quite credible and respected international news organization" and "the CNN of the Middle East spreading its news-gathering around the world in recent years", and also contacted Davies to ask about information related to the Guyer Clinic and Sly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mmqb.si.com/mmqb/2015/12/28/peyton-manning-hgh-allegations-nfl-week-16-upsets|title=The MMQB with Peter King: Upsetting Developments |website=[[Sports Illustrated]]}}</ref> [[CBS]] sportscaster and ''[[NFL on CBS]]'' #1 Play-by-play commentator [[Jim Nantz]] refused to acknowledge the report while on the air, referring to it as a "non-story".<ref>{{cite web|author=Barry Petchesky |url=http://deadspin.com/jim-nantz-is-a-sanctimonious-wiener-1750929687 |title=Jim Nantz Is A Sanctimonious Wiener |website=Deadspin |date=2015-12-28 |accessdate=2016-02-08}}</ref><ref>http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/football/jim-nantz-cbs-punt-peyton-manning-hgh-story-article-1.2484590</ref>
As part of the backlash, on January 5, 2016 it was announced that Howard and Zimmerman had filed a lawsuit suing Al Jazeera for defamation following the publication's release of the documentary which linked them.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/mlb-big-league-stew/report--ryan-zimmerman-suing-al-jazeera-after-hgh-story-230924477.html|title=Ryan Zimmerman, Ryan Howard suing Al Jazeera after steroid story|website=[[Yahoo Sports]]}}</ref> Also, Zimmerman's team, the [[Washington Nationals]], issued a statement in support of their player.<ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/dc-sports-bog/wp/2015/12/27/nationals-issue-statement-supporting-ryan-zimmerman-amid-allegations-of-ped-use/</ref>
==Further investigations== Sly said he had never seen the Mannings and told ESPN's [[Chris Mortensen]] that he is not a pharmacist and was not at the Guyer Institute in 2011, as Al Jazeera claimed, but state licensing records indicate that someone named "Charles David Sly" was licensed as a pharmacy intern in Indiana from April 2010 to May 2013 and that his license expired May 1, 2013.<ref name="abcny7">{{cite web|url=http://abc7ny.com/sports/documentary-links-peyton-manning-other-pro-athletes-to-use-of-peds/1136912 |title=Documentary links Peyton Manning, other pro athletes to use of PEDs |work=[[WABC-TV]] |date=2013-05-01 |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref> Al Jazeera later confirmed that Sly had worked at the Guyer Institute during the Fall of 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/wp/2015/12/29/al-jazeera-releases-video-to-counter-attack-on-its-doping-investigation/|title=Al Jazeera releases video to counter attack on its doping investigation|author=Erik Wemple|date=29 December 2015|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> Sly also claimed to ESPN that the reporter involved, Collins, had taken advantage of him during a vulnerable time in his life as Sly's fiancée had allegedly died, although Sly refers to his fiancée, "Karen", several times in the present tense during his conversations with Collins and gave no indication to Collins that she had died.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> Sly had also described one of the athletes mentioned, Mike Neal, as a good friend and told in the documentary he had spent about six weeks in [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]], [[Green Bay Packers|where Neal played]]; and while on Green Bay, Sly was introduced by Neal to several of his teammates, in a roster which has included players like Matthews III and [[Julius Peppers]], both whom Sly mentioned on camera. Neal served a four-game suspension for doping in [[2012 NFL season|2012]].<ref name=nyt1>https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/06/sports/baseball/al-jazeera-peyton-manning-derek-jeter-charles-sly.html?_r=0</ref><ref name="autogenerated1"/> Furthermore, the owner of the Guyer Clinic, Dale Guyer, was linked to doubtful businesses in the past.<ref>http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/football/guyer-clinic-linked-notorius-ponzi-schemer-article-1.2481062</ref>
Subsequently, ''[[The New York Times]]'' made the link between most of the names mentioned in the documentary and a sports therapy clinic called Performance Compound in [[Tampa, Florida]] run by Sly's partner Jason Riley, a fitness trainer based in [[Sarasota, Florida]]. Sly and Riley also launched ''Elementz Nutrition'', a nutritional supplement company whose website and Facebook page feature many of the athletes Sly referred. At the beginning of 2016 ''Elementz Nutrition'' voluntarily dissolved and closed its doors.<ref name=nyt1/>
On February 5, 2016, two men visited Sly's parents, and according to a 911 call from Sly's parents' house during the visit, one of the men initially said he was a law enforcement officer, but didn’t have a badge. The two men later acknowledged that they weren't law enforcement officers and stated they were looking for Sly and not his parents.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hobson |first=Will |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/inside-peyton-mannings-secret-investigation-into-al-jazeera-documentary/2016/02/04/d0da2f04-cb05-11e5-a7b2-5a2f824b02c9_story.html |title=Inside Peyton Manning’s secret investigation into Al Jazeera documentary |newspaper=The Washington Post |date= |accessdate=2016-02-08}}</ref> In response to the 911 call, the police went to the Sly house, but meanwhile, after the investigators identified themselves as private investigators, the parents decided to talk with them, and the police left. Sly's parents informed the investigators that their son was due to come home for the holidays the next day. The investigators spoke with Sly on December 23, 2015, though they refused to identify specifically who they were representing.<ref>{{cite web|author=Tom Ley |url=http://deadspin.com/here-is-the-911-call-made-from-charles-slys-home-when-p-1757319833 |title=Here Is The 911 Call Made From Charles Sly's Parents' Home When Peyton Manning's Goons Showed Up |website=Deadspin |date= |accessdate=2016-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thebiglead.com/2016/02/05/peyton-manning-hired-private-investigators-to-track-down-source-before-hgh-story-went-public/ |title=Peyton Manning Hired Private Investigators to Track Down Source Before HGH Story Went Public |website=[[The Big Lead]] |date=2014-09-18 |accessdate=2016-02-08}}</ref>
The NFL, the MLB, and later the [[United States Anti-Doping Agency|USADA]] initiated investigations into the allegations made by Sly.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stephanie Ramirez |url=http://www.wusa9.com/story/news/local/dc/2015/12/27/nat-fans-upset-over-reports-zimmerman-doping/77958502/ |title=MLB, NFL investigate reports of Zimmerman doping |work=[[WUSA-TV]] |date=2015-10-14 |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Svrluga |first=Barry |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/sports/wp/2015/12/27/nfl-mlb-will-investigate-players-named-in-al-jazeera-report/ |title=NFL, MLB will investigate players named in Al Jazeera report |publisher=The Washington Post |date= |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/mlb/story/_/id/14652385/mlb-asks-us-anti-doping-agency-help-investigate-al-jazeera-claims |title=MLB asks U.S. Anti-Doping agency to help investigate Al Jazeera claims |website=ESPN.com |date=2016-01-26 |accessdate=2016-02-08}}</ref> On April 1, 2016, Teagarden was suspended 80 games for violating the [[MLB]]'s [[Joint Drug Prevention and Treatment Program]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbssports.com/mlb/eye-on-baseball/25538782|title=Player named in Al Jazeera report suspended 80 games for PEDs|work=CBSSports.com|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref>
On June, 2016, Adolpho Birch, NFL senior vice president of labor policy and league affairs informed in a letter to the [[NFLPA]] that the league will interview the [[American football|football]] players linked to performance-enhancing drug use by the report on the first day of [[2016 NFL season|2016]] training camp.<ref>https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/2016/06/24/nfl-investigation-al-jazeera-peds/86336984/</ref> League spokesman Brian McCarthy stated via email all players will be interviewed, including Manning, despite the letter to the players union didn’t mention him as already retired Manning doesn't belong to the NFLPA anymore.<ref>http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2016/06/27/nfl-all-players-implicated-by-al-jazeera-will-be-interviewed-including-peyton-manning/</ref>
HGH was outlawed by the NFL in 1991. As part of the collective bargaining agreement in 2011, an HGH testing regime was agreed to, but testing itself for HGH didn't begin until 2014.<ref name="aljazeera1"/><ref>http://heavy.com/sports/2015/12/charles-charlie-sly-pharmacist-gave-peyton-manning-hgh-human-growth-hormone-texas-indiana-youtube-photos-al-jazeera-documentary-howard-zimmerman-james-harrison/</ref><ref>[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2005/11/051108084527.htm] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612083527/https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2005/11/051108084527.htm |date=June 12, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2011/07/25/the-cba-in-a-nutshell/ |title=The CBA in a nutshell | ProFootballTalk |website=Pro Football Talk |date=2011-07-25 |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/6834391/nfl-players-ratify-collective-bargaining-agreement-which-includes-hgh-testing-sources-say |title=NFL players ratify collective bargaining agreement, which includes HGH testing, sources say |website=ESPN.com |date=2011-08-05 |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref> It is illegal under United States federal law to prescribe HGH [[Off-label use|off label]].<ref>http://www.medscape.org/viewarticle/515665</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} <!-- After listing your sources please cite them using inline citations and place them after the information they cite. Please see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. -->
[[Category:Doping in sport]] [[Category:Al Jazeera]] [[Category:Documentaries about sports]]

{{About|the term in NFL lore|other uses|Drive (disambiguation)}} '''The Drive''' was an offensive series in the fourth quarter of the 1986 [[AFC Championship Game]] played on January 11, 1987, at [[Cleveland Municipal Stadium]] between the [[Denver Broncos]] and [[Cleveland Browns]]. Broncos quarterback [[John Elway]], in a span of 5 minutes and 2 seconds, led his team 98 yards in 15 plays to tie the game with 37 seconds left in regulation. Denver won the game in overtime making a 38 yard field goal, the Broncos pulled off a 23–20 win over the Cleveland Browns. The 98-yard drive ranks as pro football's prototypical clutch performance.{{cite web|url=http://www.profootballhof.com/history/decades/1980s/the_drive.jsp|title=Pro Football Hall of Fame – The Drive|website=ProFootballHOF.com|access-date=June 13, 2006}} Elway and his team spanned almost all of the 100-yard football field. According to an article by ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' columnist and Colorado resident [[Rick Reilly]], when Elway started the drive, Broncos [[offensive guard]] [[Keith Bishop (American football)|Keith Bishop]] said of the Browns, "We got 'em right where we want 'em!" Cleveland could not force a fourth down against Denver. The Cleveland Browns, along with lead rusher "the captain" Cory Chaney, ran for 659 yards. ==Play-by-play== The Browns had jumped to a 20–13 lead and Denver had muffed the ensuing kickoff when Elway took over, first-and-10 on their own 2-yard line, with 5:32 to play in regulation. #First down and 10, Denver 2-yard line. [[Sammy Winder]] 5-yard pass from Elway. #Second down and 5, Denver 7-yard line. Winder 3-yard run. #Third down and 2, Denver 10-yard line. Winder 2-yard run. #First down and 10, Denver 12-yard line. Winder 3-yard run. #Second down and 7, Denver 15-yard line. Elway 11-yard run. #First down and 10, Denver 26-yard line. [[Steve Sewell]] 22-yard pass from Elway. #First down and 10, Denver 48-yard line. [[Steve Watson (American football)|Steve Watson]] 12-yard pass from Elway. '''Two-minute warning''' #
  • First down and 10, Cleveland 40-yard line (1:59 left). Incomplete pass by Elway, intended for [[Vance Johnson]].
    • #Second down and 10, Cleveland 40-yard line (1:52 left). [[Dave Puzzuoli]] sack of Elway, 8-yard loss. #Third down and 18, Cleveland 48-yard line (1:47 left). [[Mark Jackson (American football player)|Mark Jackson]] 20-yard pass from Elway. #First down and 10, Cleveland 28-yard line (1:19 left). Incomplete pass by Elway, intended for Watson. #Second down and 10, Cleveland 28-yard line (1:10 left). Steve Sewell 14-yard pass from Elway. #First down and 10, Cleveland 14-yard line (:57 left). Incomplete pass by Elway, intended for Watson. #Second down and 10, Cleveland 14-yard line (:42 left). John Elway 9-yard run (scramble). #Third down and 1, Cleveland 5-yard line (:39 left). Mark Jackson 5-yard pass from Elway for the touchdown. [[Rich Karlis]] then adds the [[extra point]] to tie the game. == Game Summary == {{Americanfootballbox | titlestyle=text-align:center; background:#eee | title=Game summary| |Road='''Broncos''' |R1=0 |R2=10 |R3=3 |R4=7 |R5=3 |RT=23 |Home=Browns |H1=7 |H2=3 |H3=0 |H4=10 |H5=0 |HT=20 |stadium= [[Cleveland Stadium]], [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]] |time= 12:30 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |TV=[[NFL on NBC|NBC]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Enberg]] (play-by-play) and [[Merlin Olsen]] (color commentator) |referee= [[Chuck Heberling]] |attendance= 79,973 |scoring= *'''Scoring''' **CLE – Fontenot 6 pass from Kosar (Moseley kick) CLE 7–0 **DEN – field goal Karlis 19 CLE 7–3 **DEN – Willhite 1 run (Karlis kick) DEN 10–7 **CLE – FG Moseley 29 tie, 10–10 **DEN – FG Karlis 26 DEN 13–10 **CLE – FG Moseley 24 tie, 13–13 **CLE – Brennan 48 pass from Kosar (Moseley kick) CLE 20–13 **DEN – M. Jackson 5 pass from Elway (Karlis kick) tie, 20–20 **DEN – FG Karlis 33 DEN 23–20 }} ==Officials== *'''Referee:''' [[Chuck Heberling]] (46) *'''Umpire:''' Gordon Wells (89) *'''Head Linesman:''' [[Ed Marion]] (26) *'''Line Judge:''' Bill Reynolds (53) *'''Side Judge:''' [[Gary Lane (American football)|Gary Lane]] (120) *'''Back Judge:''' [[Ben Tompkins]] (52) *'''Field Judge:''' [[Johnny Grier]] (23) ==In popular culture== The Drive was featured in the movie ''[[Hot Tub Time Machine]]'', but due to the [[butterfly effect]], Jackson was distracted by a squirrel and failed to catch the pass and Cleveland went on to win. It was inaccurately portrayed as being in 1986 (the game was played on January 11, 1987, though it was at the end of the [[1986 NFL season]]). The movie implied that it was played at night; however, when Karlis kicked the winning field goal in OT, it was still daytime in Cleveland.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.westword.com/latestword/2010/04/john_elways_drive_never_happen.php|title=John Elway's "Drive" Never Happened?|accessdate=2010-04-20}} ==See also== *[[Cleveland sports curse]] *[[1986–87 NFL playoffs]] *[[The Fumble]] *[[Red Right 88]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{YouTube|id=C_EW5sJRKWk|title=1986 AFC Championship Game: NFL Full Game}} {{Cleveland Browns}} {{Denver Broncos}} {{NFL on NBC}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Drive, The}} [[Category:Cleveland Browns postseason]] [[Category:Denver Broncos postseason]] [[Category:1986 National Football League season]] [[Category:AFC Championship Games]] [[Category:American football incidents]] [[Category:1987 in sports in Ohio]] [[Category:20th century in Cleveland]]

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{notability|Web|date=January 2013}} {{refimprove|date=March 2013}} {{COI|date=March 2013}} }} {{Infobox Podcast |image = |caption = |hosting = Laura Coutts
Daryl Grove
Albert Ottati
Taylor Rockwell
Josh Stankus
Peyton Siddall
[[Ryan Heins]] |language = English |rss = |atom = |language_other = |rss_other = |atom_other = |updates = |length = 27+ minutes |camera = |direction = |production = |picture_format = |video_format = |audio_format = MP3 |began = 2009 |ended = |genre = Sports |ratings = |cited_for = |cited_as = |provider = |url = http://www.totalsoccershow.com }} '''''The Total Soccer Show''''' is a [[radio program]] and [[podcast]] about [[football (soccer)|football]], produced in [[Richmond, Virginia]], and broadcast locally on public radio station [[WRIR-LP]].[http://wrir.org/index.php?/schedule/ WRIR schedule] The first show was broadcast in August 2009.[http://totalsoccershow.com/about/ Total Soccer Show: About] The show is also available as a podcast, and has been part of the North American Soccer Network since December 2012.[http://nasn.tv/2012/total-soccer-show-joins-nasn/ NASN press release] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130418184130/http://nasn.tv/2012/total-soccer-show-joins-nasn/ |date=2013-04-18 }} According to Daryl Grove, the Show was named Total Soccer Show due to co-host Taylor Rockwell's love of the Total War game series. ==Hosts== * Laura Coutts * Daryl Grove * Albert Ottati * Taylor Rockwell * Peyton Siddall * Josh Stankus [http://totalsoccershow.com/about/ Total Soccer Show: About] * [[Ryan Heins]] * Shaka Smart ==Features== ===Game of the Week=== The show picks several games each week and analyzes them, as well as reporting on any and all big soccer news. In addition the show currently hosts the largest scouting database of the United States Soccer Federation. It is rumored that the USSF regularly listens in to the podcast for their scouting reports in lieu of doing any work of their own. Other national soccer federations have also been known to listen to their informative, in depth World Cup group previews as a way of preparing for upcoming World Cup group stages. Daryl and Taylor have also been credited with the landmark finding: "things can in fact be two things, and not necessarily one thing". ===The Wikipedia Game=== The co-hosts compete to name a mystery player, based on clues from his or her Wikipedia page. ===The 3-6-1 Hall of Fame=== The co-hosts profile famous names who they feel have contributed to the growth of soccer in the United States of America. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.totalsoccershow.com The Total Soccer Show website] * [http://wrir.org WRIR-LP] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130223074827/http://nasn.tv/ The North American Soccer Network] {{DEFAULTSORT:Total Soccer Show, The}} [[Category:Audio podcasts]] [[Category:Soccer media in the United States]] [[Category:Sports podcasts]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
A '''touch judge''' is an official who monitors the [[touch-line]] in a game of [[rugby union]] or [[rugby league]] and raises a flag if the ball (or player carrying it) goes into [[touch (rugby)|touch]]. Touch judges also stand behind the posts to confirm that a goal has been scored following a penalty kick or conversion of a try. There are two touch judges, one for each '''touch-line''' and each holding a different coloured flag.
==Rugby union== Rugby union touch judges support the referee by marking 'touch' (identifying when the ball leaves the playing area and comes into contact with something there or when the player carrying the ball steps out of the playing area), indicating successful kicks at goal and marking offside lines at set piece plays (the scrum and line out).
Depending on the relevant national regulations, touch judges can be recognised as 'assistant referees' and can have the authority to indicate foul play, support with pre-match protocols and other roles delegated to them by the referee.
In England, touch judges are only recognised as assistant referees when appointed by the RFU or by the relevant Referees' Society. Touch judges in the vast majority of community matches do not act as assistant referees and cannot comment on matters of foul play or other technical matters.
In [[Rugby union#Tournaments|test match]]es, it is normal for the referee and assistant referees to be connected by a radio link to aid the communication of all this information.
At elite levels of the 'sevens' variation of rugby union, additional in-goal assistant referees exist to support the referee with in-goal decisions.
==Rugby league== {{main|Rugby league match officials}} In [[rugby league]], touch judges can communicate with the referee verbally or through a number of specific flag and hand signals. These indicate specific breaches of the laws, for example [[forward pass]], knock on and [[Penalty (rugby)|penalty]] offences, how play should restart and whether the ball was grounded correctly for a try. As in rugby union, touch judges stand behind the posts to confirm success of a penalty kick or the conversion of a try. Touch judge and referee signals and duties in [[rugby league]] are laid out in the laws of the game. In some matches, additional officials are used solely to determine whether a try has been correctly grounded. These are known as "in-goal" officials.
==External links==
* [https://www.webcitation.org/5mYyri5Wv?url=http://www.therfl.co.uk/~therflc/clientdocs/rugby_laws_book_2004_.pdf Laws of Rugby League] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070829165242/http://www.irb.com/lawregulations/index.html Laws of Rugby Union]
==See also==
* [[Referee]] * [[Touch (rugby)]]
[[Category:Rugby union terminology]] [[Category:Rugby league terminology]] [[Category:Sports officiating]]

{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Tucker Stadium | nickname = | image = [[File:TuckerStadium.jpg|300px]] | location = One William L. Jones Drive
[[Cookeville,_Tennessee|Cookeville, TN]] 38501 | broke_ground = | opened = 1966 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Tennessee Technological University]] | operator = [[Tennessee Technological University]] | surface = Stadia Turf | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Tennessee Technological University]] Golden Eagles ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1966–present) | seating_capacity = 16,500 }} '''Tucker Stadium''' is a 16,500-seat [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Cookeville, Tennessee]].{{cite web| title=Tucker Stadium-Cookeville, TN|publisher=stadiumjourney.com|url=http://www.stadiumjourney.com/stadiums/tucker-stadium-s1797/|accessdate=2017-08-01}} It is home to the [[Tennessee Tech Golden Eagles football|Tennessee Technological University Golden Eagles team]], and is named for former coach, Wilburn Tucker (1920–1980). The football field is named Overall Field in honor of former coach and administrator [[Preston Vaughn Overall|P.V. Overall]]. The stadium opened in 1966 and currently seats 16,500.[http://www.ttusports.com/inside_athletics/Facilities_Photos/Tucker_Stadium_Page Tucker Stadium: Home of Golden Eagles Football]," TTUSports.com. Accessed: 1 September 2016. Tucker Stadium has hosted the [[TSSAA]] high school football state championships since 2009."[http://www.ttusports.com/sports/fball/2012-13/releases/8_14_tssaa_until_2016 Champions Are Made Here: Tucker Stadium to Host TSSAA Through 2016], TTUSports.com, 14 August 2012. ==History== ===Renovations=== In 2007, Tucker Stadium received upgrades to its playing field with the installation of artificial turf, as well as renovations and a new surface to the nine-lane track.{{cite news |title=Tucker Stadium: Home of Golden Eagle Football|url=http://www.ttusports.com/inside_athletics/Facilities_Photos/Tucker_Stadium_Page|publisher=TTUSports.com|accessdate=August 24, 2017}} In 2008, an upgraded lighting system was added to the stadium. In 2009, additional facility upgrades were performed on the press box. On August 21, 2017, Tennessee Technological University hosted a solar eclipse viewing party at Tucker Stadium, to view a [[Solar eclipse of August 21, 2017|solar eclipse]] which was viewable in [[Solar eclipse#Terminology for central eclipse|totality]] on this day.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qg3kn1aQ2QI https://www.youtube.com] Eclipse Across America (Cookeville, TN: 0:55). Prior to the 2018 football season, a new, large video scoreboard was installed. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FCS football stadiums]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.ttusports.com/inside_athletics/Facilities_Photos/Tucker_Stadium_Page Tennessee Tech Golden Eagles - Tucker Stadium] {{Tennessee Tech Golden Eagles football navbox}} {{Ohio Valley Conference football venue navbox}} {{Tennessee college football venues}} {{coord|36.178085|-85.506169|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:Tennessee Tech Golden Eagles football]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Putnam County, Tennessee]] [[Category:American football venues in Tennessee]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in the United States]] [[Category:1966 establishments in Tennessee]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1966]] {{Tennessee-sports-venue-stub}}

66,860 (2018–present) (expandable to 73,000){{cite web |title=2018 Minnesota Vikings Media Guide|url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/1rmg-vikings/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/09201320/2018-Minnesota-Vikings-Media-Guide.pdf|publisher=Minnesota Vikings|year=2018|accessdate=August 31, 2018|pages=2, 6}} | publictransit = {{rint|minnesota|blue}}
{{rint|minnesota|green}}
[[U.S. Bank Stadium (Metro Transit station)|U.S. Bank Stadium station]] | website = http://www.usbankstadium.com/ }} '''U.S. Bank Stadium''' is an enclosed [[stadium]] in [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]], [[United States]]. Built on the former site of the [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome]], the indoor stadium opened in 2016 and is the home of the [[Minnesota Vikings]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL); it also hosts early season [[college baseball]] games of the [[University of Minnesota]] [[Minnesota Golden Gophers baseball|Golden Gophers]] ([[NCAA]]). The Vikings played at the Metrodome from [[1982 Minnesota Vikings season|1982]] until its closure in 2013; during construction, the Vikings played two seasons ([[2014 Minnesota Vikings season|2014]], [[2015 Minnesota Vikings season|2015]]) at the open-air [[TCF Bank Stadium]] on the campus of the [[University of Minnesota]].{{cite web |title=Metrodome Next|url=http://www.msfc.com/tour.cfm|publisher=[[Metropolitan Sports Facilities Commission]]|accessdate=March 15, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100210094221/http://www.msfc.com/tour.cfm|archivedate=February 10, 2010|deadurl=yes}} The team's first home was [[Metropolitan Stadium]] in [[Bloomington, Minnesota|Bloomington]] {{nowrap|([[1961 Minnesota Vikings season|1961]]–[[1981 Minnesota Vikings season|1981]]),}} now the site of the [[Mall of America]]. On June 17, 2016, U.S. Bank Stadium was deemed substantially complete by contractor Mortenson Construction, six weeks before the ribbon-cutting ceremony and official grand opening on July 22. Authority to use and occupy the stadium was handed over to the Vikings and the Minnesota Sports Facilities Authority. The Vikings played their first pre-season game at U.S. Bank Stadium on August 28; the home opener of the regular season was in week two against the [[2016 Green Bay Packers season|Green Bay Packers]] on September 18, a 17–14 victory.{{cite news|last=Gibbs|first=Thom|title=Minnesota Vikings salute heroes old and new in US Bank stadium win over Green Bay Packers|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/american-football/2016/09/19/minnesota-vikings-salute-heroes-old-and-new-in-us-bank-stadium-w/|newspaper=Daily Telegraph|date=September 19, 2016|accessdate=October 1, 2016}} It is the first fixed-roof stadium built in the NFL since [[Ford Field]] in [[Detroit]], which opened in [[2002 NFL season|2002]]. As of March 2015, the overall budget was estimated to be $1.061 billion, with $348 million from the state of Minnesota, $150 million from the city of [[Minneapolis]], and $551 million from the team and private contributions. U.S. Bank Stadium hosted [[Super Bowl LII]] on February 4, 2018,{{cite news|last=Patra|first=Kevin|title=Super Bowl LII Headed to Minnesota|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap2000000352335/article/super-bowl-lii-headed-to-minneapolis|publisher=[[National Football League]]|date=May 20, 2014|accessdate=May 20, 2014}} the [[ESPN]] [[X Games]] on July 19–22, 2018, and is expected to host the 2019 [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|NCAA Final Four]], and the 2020 [[NCAA Division I Wrestling Championships]]. ==Design== [[File:New Minnesota Stadium 13 April 2015.jpg|thumb|From directly east of the stadium: the southeast facade with doors and windows going in, as well as the northeast facade with part of its exterior wall up.]] [[File:U.S. Bank construction 2 October 2015.jpg|alt=Architectural Form|thumb|US Bank Stadium under construction]] [[File:US Bank Stadium interior - Minnesota Vikings orientation.jpg|alt=US Bank Norwegian Inspiration|thumb|Transparent roof and walls]] While the Vikings' owners wanted an outdoor stadium, the state and local governments would only provide funding for an indoor stadium capable of hosting major events like the [[Super Bowl]] and the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|Final Four]]. A retractable roof, the trend in 2010s football stadiums, would have been too expensive.{{cite web |title=Vikings Unveil Design of New Stadium|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/9272021/minnesota-vikings-unveil-glass-centric-design-new-stadium|work=[[ESPN]]|date=May 14, 2013|accessdate=December 13, 2013}} Architecture firm [[HKS, Inc.]], also responsible for the [[Dallas Cowboys]]' [[AT&T Stadium]] and the [[Indianapolis Colts]]' [[Lucas Oil Stadium]], decided to go for a lightweight translucent roof and glazed entrances with giant pivoting doors, aiming to get as much natural light from the outside as possible. The roof is made up of 60% Ethylene tetrafluoroethylene ([[ETFE]]), a fluorine-based clear plastic, and is the largest in North America, spanning {{convert|240000|sqft}} supplied and installed by the firm [[Vector Foiltec]]. ETFE's low [[R-factor (crystallography)|R-factor]] and the roof's slanted design, inspired by [[Vernacular architecture in Norway|Nordic vernacular architecture]], allows the stadium to endure heavy snow loads. Snow accumulates in areas that are more safely and easily accessible, and also moves down the slanted roof into a heated gutter, the water from which drains to the nearby [[Mississippi River]]. The translucent roof and large wall panels also give fans a view of downtown Minneapolis.{{cite web|url=http://www.archdaily.com/784289/us-bank-stadium-a-game-changing-multi-purpose-nfl-stadium|title=U.S. Bank Stadium: A Game-Changing, Multi-Purpose NFL Stadium |author=Quintal, Becky|date=March 26, 2016|work=Architecture Daily|accessdate=September 17, 2016}} The glass operable wall panels will allow the stadium to experience some of the outdoor elements while providing protection from the snow, rain, and the cold winter weather.{{cite web |title=The Roof That Isn't There|first=Tim|last=Newcomb|url=http://www.popularmechanics.com/adventure/sports/a19066/minnesota-viking-football-stadium-roof/|work=[[Popular Mechanics]]|date=January 16, 2016|accessdate=June 23, 2016}} The stadium is aligned northwest and the [[elevation]] at street level is approximately {{convert|840|ft|round=5}} above [[sea level]]. ===Bird fatalities=== Years before construction began on the stadium, local and national conservation groups - including the [[Minnesota Department of Natural Resources]] and the [[Audubon Society]] - requested a "bird-friendly" design of the stadium's exterior using slightly less transparent bird-safe glass.{{cite news|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/science/birds-perish-new-vikings-stadium|title=Flocks of birds perish by crashing into new Minnesota Vikings stadium|author=Thoet, Alison|work=PBS|date=March 1, 2017|accessdate=January 31, 2018}} Designers ignored the advice and instead used highly reflective glass for aesthetic reasons. The reflective glass, combined with the stadium lying along the [[Mississippi Flyway]] migration route, has resulted in a large number of bird deaths, double any other building in Minneapolis. A "bird fatality study" being financed by the Vikings and the Minnesota Sports Facilities Authority is expected to be completed in 2019. If changes are made, it will now cost about $10 million to replace the existing glass with bird-safe glass rather than the $1 million it would have added to the original construction.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/columnist/josh-peter/2018/01/30/site-super-bowl-2018-death-trap-birds-eagles-patriots-us-bank-stadium/1079934001/|title=Site of Super Bowl LII is a death trap for birds|author=Peter, Josh|date=January 30, 2018|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=January 31, 2018}} ===Crystal Cathedral comparison=== The design for U.S. Bank Stadium has been compared to the [[Crystal Cathedral]] in [[Southern California|southern]] [[California]], which was created by architect [[Philip Johnson]].{{cite news |title=U.S. Bank Stadium Ugly on the Outside, Awesome on the Inside|first=John|last=Shipley|url=http://www.twincities.com/2016/07/19/vikings-us-bank-stadium-ugly-on-the-outside-better-interior/|newspaper=[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]|date=August 12, 2016|accessdate=October 12, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.citypages.com/arts/what-nickname-should-we-give-us-bank-stadium-poll/393686251|title=What nickname should we give US Bank Stadium? [POLL] {{!}} City Pages|last=Vondracek|first=Christopher|website=City Pages|accessdate=October 12, 2016|date=September 23, 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://cuartaygol.com/content/los-ventanales-del-us-bank-stadium|title=Los Ventanales del U.S. Bank Stadium|language=Spanish|date=October 12, 2016|newspaper=4ta & Gol|accessdate=October 12, 2016}} Opened in 1980, Crystal Cathedral was previously considered America's largest glass-dominated building.{{clarify|date=January 2017}} The stadium, which likewise sports transparent roofs, walls, and giant rotating doors, has the world's five largest pivoting doors.{{cite news |url=http://minnesota.cbslocal.com/2016/06/26/u-s-bank-stadium-doors/|title='An Engineering Feat': The Doors At U.S. Bank Stadium|last=McCoy|first=David|accessdate=October 12, 2016}} ===Capacity=== [[File:US Bank Stadium (Southeast) - Sep. 5, 2015.jpg|alt=Sharp sloping angles|thumb|Dark facade side of stadium]] The [[seating capacity]] is 66,860 for most games, slightly more than the Metrodome, and can be expanded to 73,000 for soccer, concerts, and special events, such as the Super Bowl.{{cite web |title=New Vikings Stadium Facts and Figures|url=http://www.vikings.com/news/article-1/New-Vikings-Stadium-Facts-and-Figures/7b3cb5b4-0979-4e3a-b08a-12760787dd13|publisher=Minnesota Vikings|date=May 13, 2013|accessdate=December 3, 2013}}{{cite news |title=U.S. Bank Stadium: What It cost and By the Numbers|first=Brian|last=Murphy|url=https://www.twincities.com/2016/07/31/u-s-bank-stadium-by-the-numbers/|newspaper=[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]|date=July 31, 2016|accessdate=January 18, 2018}} ====Attendance record for 2016 season[https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2016/attendance.htm "2016 NFL Attendance Data"]. Pro Football Reference. Last modified 2017. Retrieved October 27, 2017.==== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Minnesota Vikings|border=2}};|Opponent
